experiments.readout: Absence of PAH activity

result.effect_size_and_stats: No PAH activity detected in extracts from cells transfected with mutant PAH cDNA.

summary: The study matches the TARGET_VARIANT through an identified splice donor site mutation (GT to AT) causing exon 12 skipping. experiments.variant_material: cDNA from peripheral blood samples of affected individuals
experiments.readout: Percentages of different transcripts calculated based on peak heights of individual fragments

result.effect_size_and_stats: Significantly reduced wild-type transcript to 48% in patients vs. 66% in controls (p<0.01) with the 32nt deleted transcript at 15%, absent in controls.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Used eight unrelated controls without the variant for comparison.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The presence of the novel transcript indicates disruption and abolishment of normal splicing due to the variant.
caveats: No mention of replicates for fragment analysis controls.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Multiple controls and segregation data supporting pathogenicity. Significant statistical analysis indicates functional abnormalities due to splicing disruption.
overall_evidence.basis: The evidence shows that the c.1679C>G variant abolishes normal splicing and is consistent with a pathogenic mutation.

summary: The CDH1 variant c.1679C>G (p.T560R) matched with high confidence as it was assessed for its genomic and functional consequences in the paper. The fragment analysis demonstrated significant disruptions in normal splicing with strong evidence for pathogenicity, leading to a PS3 classification.

experiments.variant_material: Purified PTEN variants
experiments.readout: kcat/KM values measured at 25 °C

result.effect_size_and_stats: kcat/KM value of (4.5 ± 0.4) μM−1min−1, which is 3% that of the wild-type enzyme.

experiments.authors_conclusion: H93R PTEN has low catalytic activity due to impaired binding to PIP2, affecting its phosphatase function.
caveats: H93R variant has low Tm of (38.1 ± 0.3) °C, indicating potential stability issues.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: The enzymatic activity was directly measured and compared to wild-type PTEN with additional statistical analysis based on kcat/KM ratios.
overall_evidence.basis: The H93R variant exhibits significantly reduced catalytic activity and stability compared to wild-type PTEN, consistent with pathogenic potential.

summary: The H93R variant in the PTEN gene corresponds to a well-documented functional study showing impaired catalytic activity (3% of wild-type) and reduced thermodynamic stability. The evidence level for this variant is classified as PS3, supported by experimental data demonstrating functionally abnormal results.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Includes negative control C124S PTEN with no activity reported.
experiments.authors_conclusion: H93R PTEN retains some catalytic activity but is significantly diminished compared to wild-type PTEN.

experiments.system: Binding assays with lipid vesicles containing PS and PI(4,5)P2
experiments.variant_material: H93R PTEN affinity to lipid membranes
experiments.readout: Binding affinity measurements presented
experiments.normal_comparator: Not applicable; comparison made with WT

experiments.controls_and_validation: Binding constants calculated for lipid interactions were compared to those of wild-type PTEN.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The mutation alters the binding affinity and functionality of PTEN at membranes, impacting its activity despite increased membrane association.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Phosphatase activity shown to be significantly less active relative to wild type, with binding assays confirming functional impairment.
overall_evidence.basis: H93R PTEN exhibits reduced phosphatase activity (15% of WT) and altered binding characteristics, indicating a functional abnormality consistent with disease mechanism.

summary: The H93R mutation in PTEN was matched as it specifically corresponds to a known variant in the study. notes: PlA2 polymorphism mentioned multiple times, correlating with the variants and functional studies on integrin αIIbβ3.

experiments.variant_material: Stable CHO cell lines expressing PlA1 and PlA2
experiments.readout: Percent adhesion to immobilized fibrinogen

result.effect_size_and_stats: A2 cells demonstrated 80% greater adhesion at 2.5 µg/mL (P < 0.001), 60% greater at 5 µg/mL (P < 0.001) compared to A1 cells.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Comparison to LK444 control and inhibition studies showed specificity to αIIbβ3.
experiments.authors_conclusion: A2 cells exhibit enhanced adhesion in an αIIbβ3-dependent manner compared to A1 cells.
caveats: Results based on adhesive assays under static conditions may not fully represent in vivo conditions.

experiments.variant_material: Stable CHO cell lines expressing PlA1 and PlA2
experiments.readout: Percent clot retraction

result.effect_size_and_stats: A2 cells exhibited a small but significant increase in clot retraction compared to A1 cells at all time points.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Clot retraction inhibited by an αIIbβ3-specific peptide; comparison with control cells indicated specificity.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The PlA2 form demonstrates greater clot retraction, implicating a more robust integrin-mediated signaling.
caveats: The clot retraction studies are based on in vitro assays and may not directly correlate with patient outcomes.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Rigorous comparison of A1 and A2 variants with controls, significant increases in adhesion and clot retraction with statistical validations reported.
overall_evidence.basis: The A2 variant shows functionally abnormal results in adhesion and clot retraction assays compared with A1, supporting a prothrombotic feature linked to the variant.

summary: The study found that the PlA2 variant (p.Leu59Pro) in ITGB3 significantly enhances platelet adhesion and clot retraction compared to the PlA1 variant, indicating a functionally abnormal result consistent with a damaging effect.

notes: Highly equivalent genomic and protein change labels were found in the paper.

experiments.system: Single FDB fibers from Y522S-RYR1 mice and wild-type control
experiments.variant_material: Single flexor digitorum brevis (FDB) muscle fibers isolated from YS and WT mice
experiments.readout: Calcium concentration levels measured by fluorescence ratio changes

result.effect_size_and_stats: YS fibers show significantly higher resting [Ca2+] and peak [Ca2+] values after caffeine stimulation than WT fibers.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Control experiments were conducted with WT fibers for comparisons.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Increased mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake is linked to enhanced contractility in Y522S-RYR1 fibers.
caveats: The transfectants utilized were solely from YS and WT lines, limiting external validation of results.

experiments.assay: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) assessment using MitoSOX
experiments.system: FDB fibers isolated from Y522S-RYR1 mice
experiments.variant_material: FDB muscle fibers transfected with MitoSOX
experiments.readout: MitoSOX fluorescence intensity as a marker of mitochondrial ROS production

result.effect_size_and_stats: Increased ROS accumulation in YS fibers after caffeine exposure compared to WT.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Controls used included WT fibers under the same experimental conditions for comparison.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Mitochondrial ROS production in Y522S fibers contributes to Ca2+ release and contributes to MH susceptibility.
caveats: MitoSOX staining may have variability based on fiber viability and transfection efficiency.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Multiple experiments with statistical significance comparing Y522S to WT mouse models showed consistent alteration in Ca2+ handling and ROS production, indicating pathogenic functional consequences of the variant.
overall_evidence.basis: The Y522S variant significantly enhances mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake and ROS production, both of which are critical in the etiology of malignant hyperthermia.

summary: The study identifies the Y522S-RYR1 variant as critical for altered calcium dynamics and enhanced mitochondrial ROS production in mice, leading to a PS3 classification. Strong evidence is supported by comparative functional analyses in both experimental YS and WT muscle fibers.

caveats: Variation in mitochondrial function could be influenced by nuclear genetic background, though state III/DNP and ADP/O ratios remained consistent between experimental conditions.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: variant-level correlation in cybrid experiments coupled with significant biochemical impairment consistent across multiple mutational contexts
overall_evidence.basis: decreased state III respiration and ADP/O ratio directly linked to the mtDNA mutation, indicative of functional impairment of the ATP synthase.

summary: The study matches the chrM_8993_T_G variant to the T -> G mutation at nt 8993 in the ATP6 gene, demonstrating significantly reduced state III respiration and ADP/O ratios in patient-derived cybrids compared to controls. target_variant_input: Gene: RYR1, chr_pos_ref_alt (hg38): chr19_38500898_C_T, chr_pos_ref_alt (hg37): chr19_38991538_C_T, HGVSg (hg38): g.38500898C>T, HGVSg (hg37): g.38991538C>T, rsID: rs118192178, HGVSc: c.7522C>T, HGVSp (3-letter): p.Arg2508Cys, HGVSp (1-letter): p.R2508C

notes: Variant p.Arg2509C is the equivalent human mutation corresponding to p.Arg2508C in humans, indicating a high match confidence.

experiments.system: Isolated flexor digitorum brevis muscle cells
experiments.variant_material: FDB muscle cells isolated from R2509C mice
experiments.readout: [Ca2+]i levels

result.effect_size_and_stats: Resting [Ca2+]i significantly higher in R2509C cells than in WT (p<0.001) and Cpd1 treatment reduced [Ca2+]i in R2509C cells.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Experiments included controls using WT cells to compare [Ca2+]i levels.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Cpd1 significantly reduced elevated [Ca2+]i levels in R2509C cells, demonstrating its effectiveness in correcting calcium homeostasis.
caveats: The study was limited to in vitro conditions, which may not fully replicate in vivo dynamics.
Potential species differences in RYR1 response.

experiments.system: Soleus muscles isolated from R2509C mice
experiments.variant_material: Soleus muscles from R2509C and WT mice
experiments.readout: Contracture force in response to caffeine

result.effect_size_and_stats: Pretreatment with Cpd1 reduced caffeine-induced contracture tension in R2509C muscles compared to vehicle treatment.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Caffeine concentrations were standardized for both R2509C and WT muscle assessments.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Cpd1 is effective in reducing contracture forces in R2509C muscles, indicating a correction of the hypercontractility associated with the mutation.
caveats: Control comparisons to other agents were not included for broader context.
Variability in muscle response was noted.

experiments.variant_material: RYR1-p.R2509C mice
experiments.readout: Rectal temperature changes and survival rates

result.effect_size_and_stats: Cpd1 significantly prevented isoflurane-induced temperature rise (p<0.01) in treated mice compared to controls.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Baseline temperature monitoring ensured starting conditions were equivalent across groups.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Cpd1 effectively prevents maligned hyperthermia events triggered by isoflurane, confirming its therapeutic potential.
caveats: Timing of administration in relation to anesthesia varied among subjects.
Further studies are necessary to measure long-term efficacy.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Multiple controls and dose response assessments were conducted, showcasing significant separation from wild-type performance with Cpd1 treatment.
overall_evidence.basis: Cpd1 demonstrated functionally abnormal behaviors consistent with RYR1 mutation mechanisms, with significant efficacy in calcium handling and contractility.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT p.Arg2509C has been matched based on genomic coordinates and RSID. Functional experiments demonstrate that Cpd1 effectively corrects calcium dysregulation and prevents malignant hyperthermia in RYR1-p.R2509C mice. The evidence supports a PS3 classification due to strong functional abnormality association with the variant.

summary: The p.G2435R variant of RYR1 was heuristically matched to the TARGET_VARIANT p.G2434R through functional assessments showing abnormal Ca2+ handling in both myotubes and intact mice. experiments.variant_material: cDNA mixtures injected into myotube nuclei
experiments.readout: Ca2+ release sensitivity (EC50 value)

experiments.authors_conclusion: The R3983C mutation results in an increase in caffeine-induced Ca2+ release sensitivity.
caveats: The increase in sensitivity might depend on the expression levels in myotubes.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Controlled experiments with known pathogenic and benign variants provide validation for the observed effects.
overall_evidence.basis: The R3983C variant resulted in a functionally abnormal outcome demonstrating increased Ca2+ release sensitivity compared to WT, supporting its pathogenic role.

summary: The R3983C variant was matched based on genomic coordinate and functional experiments demonstrated increased caffeine sensitivity correlating with malignant hyperthermia susceptibility, meeting PS3 strong criteria.

notes: The T4709M mutation is referenced multiple times in relation to the generated Ryr1TM/Indel mice model, establishing a clear match with the TARGET_VARIANT.

experiments.system: Isolated EDL muscles from mouse model
experiments.variant_material: Extracted from Ryr1TM/Indel mice
experiments.readout: Peak twitch and tetanic-specific force

result.effect_size_and_stats: Peak twitch force significantly reduced in Ryr1TM/Indel (15.6 ± 3.2 mN/mm²) compared to WT (27.4 ± 3.7 mN/mm²); P < 0.001 for tetanic force, also significantly lower.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Used WT mice as controls, specific force was normalized for physiological cross-sectional area, ensuring reliability of results.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The Ryr1TM/Indel mice exhibit significantly impaired muscle contraction dynamics indicated by lower force production in EDL muscles.
caveats: Statistical measures were applied, but no mention of a repeated measures across multiple trials in the same cohort to confirm reliability beyond sample size.

experiments.system: Single FDB muscle fibers isolated from the footpad of Ryr1TM/Indel mice
experiments.variant_material: FDB muscle fibers from Ryr1TM/Indel mice
experiments.readout: Peak Ca²⁺ transient amplitude

result.effect_size_and_stats: Significantly reduced peak Ca²⁺ transient amplitude during electrically evoked twitch (4.9 ± 0.7% F/F0) compared to WT (12.3 ± 1.4% F/F0); P < 0.001.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Measurements confirmed with multiple trials in FDB fibers isolated from different subjects.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Ryr1TM/Indel mice show significant impairment in intracellular Ca²⁺ dynamics, impacting muscle contraction.
caveats: No mention of long-term stability of calcium dynamics across a broader range of temperature or stimuli.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Functional studies show a significant functional impairment in both muscle force production and Ca²⁺ release compared to WT, with clear methodological rigor employed in experiments.
overall_evidence.basis: The Ryr1TM/Indel mouse model, corresponding directly to the T4709M mutation, exhibits a clear functional breakdown and muscle pathology consistent with severe RYR1-related myopathy.

summary: The matching of the T4709M mutation from the RYR1 gene in the generated Ryr1TM/Indel mice has identified two functional experiments demonstrating significant reductions in muscle function and Ca²⁺ release. PS3 evidence is confirmed from these functional abnormalities, supporting strong pathogenicity.

notes: Exact suffix matches for the genomic coordinates and cDNA level are present. The variant's functional details are discussed in relation to VLCAD deficiency.

experiments.system: Patient-derived mesenchymal stem cells (BA-28, BA-38) and control cells (Hs27)
experiments.variant_material: Mesenchymal stem cells isolated from skin biopsies
experiments.readout: Metabolic activity

result.effect_size_and_stats: 65–85% less metabolic activity than Hs27 cells (P < 0.05)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Multiple independent experiments confirmed consistent results across both patient samples.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Patient-derived cells showed significantly reduced metabolic activity compared to controls, suggesting functional impairment due to the c.65C>A mutation.
caveats: Limited to two patient samples, but the results were consistent.
Controls were derived from a single cell line.

experiments.variant_material: Mesenchymal stem cells
experiments.readout: Cell proliferation rate

result.effect_size_and_stats: Significantly lower proliferation rates in patient cells compared to control cells (P < 0.05)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Control Hs27 cells showed normal proliferation rates, confirming the impairment in patient cells.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The mutation was shown to significantly affect the proliferation ability of the stem cells.
caveats: Direct comparison to control cells only.

experiments.system: Monolayer cultures of patient-derived mesenchymal stem cells and control cells
experiments.variant_material: Skin-derived mesenchymal stem cells
experiments.readout: Wound closure rate

result.effect_size_and_stats: 40% less ability to heal compared to Hs27 cells within 24 hours (P < 0.05)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Assays were repeated with consistent results across both patient cell lines.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The ACADVL mutation leads to impaired wound healing capacity in stem cells from VLCAD-deficient patients.
caveats: Wound healing ability was only assessed within a 24-hour period.

experiments.system: Patient-derived cells and CRISPR-modified normal cells (Hs27)
experiments.variant_material: Skin mesenchymal stem cells from patients and normal cells
experiments.readout: Glucose uptake rate

result.effect_size_and_stats: 80–90% reduction in glucose uptake in patient cells compared to normal cells (P < 0.01)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Normal cells showed expected glucose uptake; mutation introduction replicated the defect.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The defect in glucose uptake was directly attributed to the presence of the c.65C>A mutation.
caveats: Further investigations are needed to evaluate GLUT expression in other tissues.
Comparative GLUT1 expression levels were the same in both groups, suggesting the uptake issues lie elsewhere.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Rigorous experimental design with controls and consistent results across multiple functional assays using patient-derived cells and CRISPR-modified controls, supporting the pathogenic effect of the c.65C>A mutation in ACADVL.
overall_evidence.basis: The presence of significant functional abnormalities in multiple assays strengthens the link of the c.65C>A variant to VLCAD deficiency.

summary: The study confirms the pathogenic effect of the c.65C>A variant in the ACADVL gene, linked to VLCAD deficiency, through various assays indicating functional impairments in mesenchymal stem cells.

experiments.readout: Detection of pro-αIIb and mature αIIb

summary: The G128S variant relates to p.Gly159Ser described in the manuscript, supported by immunoblot assays showing no mature αIIb. This variant demonstrates a clear defect in transport out of the ER, categorized under PS3 evidence due to its marked functional abnormality.

experiments.variant_material: Cybrids carrying the 3302A>G mutation
experiments.readout: Respiration rate (fmol O2/cell·min)

result.effect_size_and_stats: 6-fold reduction of respiration, from 4 to 0.6 fmol O2/cell·min.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Parental 143B cells and cybrid clones with varying levels of the mutation
experiments.authors_conclusion: The 3302A>G mutation causes a dramatic defect in respiratory chain function in cybrid cells.

experiments.readout: Levels of mt-tRNALeu(UUR)

experiments.readout: Degree of aminoacylation of mt-tRNALeu(UUR)

experiments.authors_conclusion: A decrease in aminoacylation contributes to the dysfunction associated with the mutation.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Extensive functional assays demonstrated deficiency in respiration, tRNA levels, and aminoacylation associated with the mutation.

summary: The 3302A>G variant in mt-tRNALeu(UUR) has been matched based on clear labeling in the paper. Functional experiments show significant impairment of respiration and tRNA levels, fulfilling PS3 criteria for a damaging variant.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Comparison against control group
experiments.authors_conclusion: Significant dysfunction observed in RGCs due to mutant hND1 injection

experiments.variant_material: Extracted from eyes injected with mutant human ND1

experiments.authors_conclusion: Mutant hND1 significantly impairs complex I function

experiments.readout: Quantification of RGCs

result.effect_size_and_stats: 39% RGC loss compared to control (2360±887 vs. 3856±743 cells/mm2, P<0.01)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Comparison with untreated groups
experiments.authors_conclusion: Significant loss of RGCs attributable to mutant hND1

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Multiple assays demonstrating functional abnormality, including direct comparisons with controls in multiple contexts.
overall_evidence.basis: The repeated demonstration of functional abnormalities linked to the mutant ND1 gene supports its role in the pathogenic mechanism associated with LHON.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT matches the mutant hND1/m.3460G>A identified in the study. Three functional experiments demonstrate significant impairments in RGC function and complex I activity, leading to strong PS3 evidence supporting pathogenicity.

target_variant_input: Gene: MYOC, chr_pos_ref_alt (hg38): chr1_171636092_T_A, chr_pos_ref_alt (hg37): chr1_171605232_T_A, HGVSg (hg38): g.171636092T>A, HGVSg (hg37): g.171605232T>A, rsID: N/A, HGVSc: c.1348A>T, HGVSp (3-letter): p.Asn450Tyr, HGVSp (1-letter): p.N450Y

notes: The variant is explicitly mentioned as N450Y and linked to functional assays in multiple sections of the paper.

experiments.variant_material: HTM cells infected with MYOC-N450Y lentivirus
experiments.readout: Protein levels of LC3B and p62

result.effect_size_and_stats: Increased LC3B and decreased p62 in MYOC-N450Y groups compared to MYOC-WT, indicating autophagy activation.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Comparison with MYOC-WT controls; validation through multiple assays including Western blot and flow cytometry.
experiments.authors_conclusion: MYOC-N450Y activates autophagy in HTM cells and impairs cell viability and apoptosis.

experiments.variant_material: HTM cells expressing MYOC-N450Y
experiments.readout: Cell viability measured by absorbance at 450 nm

result.effect_size_and_stats: Decreased cell viability in MYOC-N450Y compared to MYOC-WT. Chloroquine treatment rescued viability.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Controls included untreated MYOC-WT and MYOC-N450Y groups.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Chloroquine treatment reduces cell death and rescues viability in MYOC-N450Y expressing cells.

experiments.variant_material: Tg-MYOCN450Y mice
experiments.readout: Gadolinium signal tracking for aqueous humor outflow

result.effect_size_and_stats: Altered aqueous humor dynamics indicated by increased Gd signal accumulation in Tg-MYOCN450Y mice compared to WT mice.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Multiple time points (4 months to 12 months) assessed for dynamics compared to WT controls.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Tg-MYOCN450Y mice exhibit glaucoma phenotypes with altered aqueous humor outflow.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Multiple validation controls including WT comparison and rigorous assessment of IOP and visual function in vivo.
overall_evidence.basis: MYOC-N450Y activates autophagy leading to detrimental effects in trabecular meshwork cells, consistently observed across in vitro and in vivo experiments.

summary: The study successfully identifies MYOC-N450Y as a variant associated with glaucomatous pathogenesis through functional assays demonstrating autophagy activation and impaired cell viability. Overall, evidence supports a PS3 classification with strong confidence based on significant experimental results across multiple systems.

experiments.variant_material: BAC transgenic mice expressing Tyr437His mutant of MYOC
experiments.readout: Myocilin levels in eye tissues

result.effect_size_and_stats: 2-3 fold increase in myocilin compared to WT

experiments.controls_and_validation: Western blot with actin as normalization control.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Expression of mutated myocilin resulted in elevated levels in tissues and blocked secretion into aqueous humor.
caveats: None stated in the paper for this assay.

experiments.variant_material: Transgenic mice expressing Tyr437His mutant of MYOC
experiments.readout: Intraocular pressure (IOP) measurements

result.effect_size_and_stats: IOP was approximately 2 mm Hg higher in transgenic than WT during the day and 3.4 mm Hg higher at night.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Statistical analysis with Student’s t-test was performed.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The expression of human MYOC causes measurable elevation of IOP consistent with glaucoma.
caveats: Baseline IOP levels were not reported before mutations were introduced.

experiments.assay: Retrograde Labeling of Retinal Ganglion Cells
experiments.variant_material: Transgenic mice expressing Tyr437His mutant of MYOC
experiments.readout: Density of retinal ganglion cells

result.effect_size_and_stats: 20% loss in retinal ganglion cells in peripheral retina of transgenic mice.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Analyses were performed in a masked fashion.
experiments.authors_conclusion: Mutated MYOC expression leads to significant retinal ganglion cell loss, a hallmark of glaucoma.
caveats: Only peripheral retina analyzed, central retina not affected.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Multiple functional assays with significant controls and replication validation.
overall_evidence.basis: The experiments consistently show functionally abnormal results in IOP elevation and retinal ganglion cell degeneration tied to expression of the mutant MYOC.

summary: The study provides clear evidence linking the Tyr437His mutant of MYOC to glaucoma pathology through multiple functional assays, demonstrating elevated IOP and retinal damage consistent with primary open-angle glaucoma.

experiments.variant_material: Mouse platelets from Vwf/p.V1316M (KI) mice
experiments.readout: Bleeding time (seconds)

result.effect_size_and_stats: None of the KI mice stopped bleeding within 10 minutes; average bleeding time for WT was 78±11 s.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Platelets from WT and HET mice were used as controls.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The p.V1316M mutation leads to a severe bleeding phenotype in KI mice, indicating dysfunction in hemostasis.
caveats: The assay results are limited to a specific context (tail bleeding model) and might not generalize to all scenarios.

experiments.variant_material: Mouse platelets from Vwf/p.V1316M (KI) mice
experiments.readout: Occlusion time (minutes)

result.effect_size_and_stats: No occlusion of venules or arterioles within the 60-min observation period for KI mice.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Thrombus formation was also monitored in WT and HET mice for comparison.
experiments.authors_conclusion: KI mice exhibit severe thrombosis defects, further indicating impaired functionality due to the p.V1316M mutation.
caveats: Observed only in specific conditions and may not reflect all aspects of thrombosis.

experiments.assay: Whole blood perfusion assay on collagen matrix
experiments.system: Mouse model (whole blood from Vwf/p.V1316M mice)
experiments.variant_material: Anticoagulated blood from KI, HET, and WT mice
experiments.readout: Platelet adhesion percentage

result.effect_size_and_stats: Platelet adhesion was markedly reduced to 29.4±2.3% (venous shear) and 39.7±6.5% (arterial shear) for KI compared to WT.

experiments.controls_and_validation: Multiple trials performed to assess the reproducibility.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The p.V1316M mutation severely impairs platelet adhesion under flow conditions, contributing to its clinical phenotype.
caveats: Platelet counts were not normalized before perfusion, which could influence adhesion measurements.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Comparative controls and well-established assays were used throughout the experiments, confirming the specific functional consequences of the mutation.
overall_evidence.basis: Multiple functional assays consistently demonstrate a severe defect in hemostasis and thrombosis for the p.V1316M variant, relevant to the disease mechanism of VWD type 2B.

summary: The variant p.V1316M in the VWF gene was matched based on its identification in the paper by multiple references including rsID and amino acid change. summary: The R1399H variant in the VWF gene was matched, showing significant functional impairment in type VI collagen binding through recombinant expression studies. This supports a PS3 classification with strong evidence, indicating a damaging effect related to von Willebrand disease.

summary: The variant I1628T (c.4883T>C) matched the TARGET_VARIANT with medium confidence based on the cDNA change. Cleavage assays showed that this variant markedly increased susceptibility to ADAMTS13 cleavage, supporting a PS3 classification with strong functional evidence.

experiments.variant_material: recombinant human NaV1.1 channel
experiments.readout: sodium current

result.effect_size_and_stats: Increased persistent current compared to WT-NaV1.1 (1.48 ± 0.19%, n = 7, P ≤ 0.01)

experiments.controls_and_validation: WT-NaV1.1
experiments.authors_conclusion: The Q1489K mutation leads to a predominantly loss-of-function phenotype as it exhibits increased persistent current and impaired inactivation kinetics.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Use of WT-NaV1.1 as a comparator with significant differences in functional assays demonstrating abnormal persistent currents and inactivation properties.
overall_evidence.basis: The evidence from functional assays shows that Q1489K exhibits increased persistent current and altered inactivation dynamics compared to wild-type, fulfilling the criteria for PS3.

summary: The paper characterizes the Q1489K variant in SCN1A associated with FHM3, providing evidence of functional defects such as increased persistent sodium current. The evidence is categorized as PS3, with strong support due to clear experimental validation against a wild-type control.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Clear experimental replication and comparison with wild-type controls demonstrate functional abnormalities.
overall_evidence.basis: Q1478K shows gain of function in neuronal excitability leading to increased firing rates compared to wild-type, consistent with pathogenic effects in migraine.

summary: The variant Q1489K (Q1478K in the study) was successfully matched to the paper. experiments.system: Gastrocnemius muscle in ACTA1 H40Y mouse model
experiments.variant_material: Mouse (H40Y mutation)
experiments.readout: Maximal force production, specific force, fatigue index

result.effect_size_and_stats: 40% reduction in absolute maximal tetanic force; 25% reduction in specific tetanic force; significantly lower FTI in H40Y mice compared to controls (1.25 ± 0.01 mN.sec/mm3 vs 1.48 ± 0.03 mN.sec/mm3)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Control muscle samples from wild-type mice; statistical significance was determined through ANOVA with post-hoc tests.
experiments.authors_conclusion: The H40Y mutation leads to reduced specific force production, which may be related to intrinsic muscle properties.
caveats: Standard controls in experiments; limitations noted regarding muscle atrophy being a factor in force production reduction.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Clear comparison with wild-type controls demonstrating muscle weakness and altered energy metabolism in the H40Y model, corroborated by functional assays.
overall_evidence.basis: The H40Y mutation shows functionally abnormal results consistent with reduced muscle force production, aligning with the disease mechanism of nemaline myopathy.

summary: The H40Y variant in the ACTA1 gene is matched with high confidence. Functional experiments show significant reductions in muscle force production in the H40Y mouse model compared to wild-type controls, supporting a PS3 classification for pathogenicity.

experiments.readout: RT-PCR products showing exon skipping

summary: The matching of the TARGET_VARIANT was established through the identification of c.1312+4_1312+19del in the APC gene, correlating to a splice donor variant known for its pathogenic effects causing familial adenomatous polyposis. notes: The paper presents evidence of the splicing mutation at IVS9+5G>A which produces a frameshift and inefficient exon skipping, consistent with the TARGET_VARIANT.

experiments.readout: Abnormal splice transcript and normal transcripts visualized on 6% PAGE
experiments.normal_comparator: Normal individuals and other FAP patients with identified mutations

result.effect_size_and_stats: Novel shorter transcript (336 bp) amplified only from the proband's RNA, indicating abnormal splicing.

overall_evidence.basis: The presence of a novel shorter transcript indicates a damaging effect consistent with the known pathogenic mechanism of splicing mutation.

summary: The variant IVS9+5G>A identified in this study corresponds to the TARGET_VARIANT. Functional studies showed that this variant results in abnormal splicing leading to functional impairment. target_variant_input: Gene: KCNQ1, chr_pos_ref_alt (hg38): chr11_2572882_C_T, chr_pos_ref_alt (hg37): chr11_2594112_C_T, HGVSg (hg38): g.2572882C>T, HGVSg (hg37): g.2594112C>T, rsID: rs120074180, HGVSc: c.817C>T, HGVSp (3-letter): p.Leu273Phe, HGVSp (1-letter): p.L273F

notes: The L273F mutation was introduced into concatenated tetrameric channels and its effects were assessed, leading to a direct match with the TARGET_VARIANT.

experiments.variant_material: Concatenated tetrameric Kv7.1 construct with L273F mutation
experiments.readout: Inactivation kinetics

result.effect_size_and_stats: Significant increase in recovery time from inactivation; recovery time with 4 L273F subunits was measured at 379 ± 27 ms (n = 4); compared to ConLFLL at 150 ± 11 ms (n = 4).

experiments.controls_and_validation: Comparison with WT and various L273F mutant combinations
experiments.authors_conclusion: Incorporating L273F into Kv7.1 progressively slows recovery from inactivation, suggesting that Kv7.1 slow macroscopic inactivation is not compatible with a concerted cooperative process.
caveats: Recovery time varies based on the number of L273F subunits incorporated.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Electrophysiological data shows a significant change in function (increased recovery time), consistent with damaging effects and disease mechanisms related to long QT syndrome.
overall_evidence.basis: The functional experiments indicate that the variant causes a significant abnormality in channel kinetics, reinforcing its pathogenic potential in the context of KCNQ1 mutations.

summary: The study matched the KCNQ1 L273F variant, revealing that the incorporation of this mutation into concatenated Kv7.1 channels leads to slower recovery from inactivation, consistent with a damaging effect on function and confirming its relevance as a pathogenic variant as per PS3 guidelines.

overall_evidence.basis: Mutant PAH cDNA mimicking exon 12 skip shows complete loss of enzyme activity and protein stability in COS cells, consistent with PKU mechanism; linking to c.1315+1G>A is high confidence

summary: The PAH c.1315+1G>A splice site mutation, described as a GT->AT transition at the intron 12 donor site, was matched with high confidence. COS cell expression of a cDNA construct mimicking the resulting exon 12-skipped transcript demonstrated complete loss of PAH enzymatic activity and absence of stable protein, despite normal mRNA levels, and S1 nuclease protection confirmed exon 12 skipping in patient liver RNA. These results provide strong functional evidence of a damaging effect consistent with classic PKU. PS3 is applied at moderate strength.

summary: The variant p.M35V was explicitly tested in this PTEN functional variomics study. In yeast Δvac14 genetic interaction assays and Drosophila eclosion assays, M35V exhibited complete loss-of-function relative to WT. In HEK293 cells, M35V markedly reduced PTEN protein stability and acted as a dominant negative in insulin-stimulated AKT phosphorylation. These consistent dysfunctional results across multiple models support a PS3 moderate evidence classification for this variant.

summary: The p.Arg719Trp (RW) mutation in MYH7 is directly modeled as RW/+ and RW/RW in the mouse α-MHC gene, with variant labels matching explicitly (Fig. 2A, 2B, 4A, 4B). RW/+ mice show concentric hypertrophy and increased fractional shortening (43±3% vs 38±3% wt, p<0.05) alongside myofiber disarray and interstitial fibrosis, while RW/RW mice exhibit early lethality by day 9 and marked upregulation of ANP (11.2±3.5-fold) and BNP (4.5±0.7-fold, p<0.001). These robust in vivo data demonstrate functionally abnormal effects consistent with HCM disease mechanism, supporting a PS3_moderate level of evidence for pathogenicity.

summary: The p.Ser532Pro (S532P) variant in MYH7 was directly modeled in murine α-cardiac myosin and labeled S532P in the paper. Purified S532P myosin exhibited a 40% reduction in actin filament velocity and a 24% decrease in step size with increased attachment duration compared with WT, while average isometric force was unchanged. These functionally abnormal results support PS3 at a supporting level for a damaging effect.

summary: The paper describes functional assays on skinned ventricular strips from S532P/+ heterozygous mice expressing the p.Ser532Pro mutation in α-MyHC. Calcium-activated tension measurements showed no difference between S532P/+ and WT (functionally normal). Sinusoidal length perturbation analysis revealed a significantly higher rate of force development (2πb) and modeling of detachment rates indicated an elevated MgATP binding rate (k+ATP) in S532P/+ versus WT, consistent with a damaging effect. Overall, these well-controlled assays provide moderate PS3-level evidence supporting a functional abnormality caused by p.S532P.

In transiently transfected HEK293 cells, SOS1-HF yields increased ERK phosphorylation compared with WT (∼1.5-fold; P<0.05), indicating gain-of-function; real-time NMR of 15N-RAS exchange showed similar intrinsic rates to WT. summary: The paper describes the SHOC2 c.4A>G (Ser2Gly, S2G) variant, matched via exact cDNA and protein notation. Functional assays show SHOC2S2G is aberrantly myristoylated, constitutively targeted to the plasma membrane, enhances EGF-stimulated ERK phosphorylation, and produces neomorphic vulval phenotypes in C. elegans. These well-controlled, replicated studies support a damaging gain-of-function effect, consistent with PS3_moderate evidence.

summary: The c.65A>G (p.Q22R) variant was directly matched by the exact protein notation p.Q22R in the paper. In COS-7 cell pull-down assays, KRASQ22R accumulated in the GTP-bound state (~4–5-fold higher than WT), but in vitro assays showed intrinsic and GEF-catalyzed exchange and GAP-stimulated hydrolysis equivalent to wild-type. A fluorescence polarization assay revealed a ~6.4-fold reduction in RAF1-RBD binding affinity. These mixed findings (gain in active state vs. impaired effector interaction) leave the functional impact unclear; therefore, PS3/BS3 cannot be applied (evidence_level=not_clear).

summary: The paper clearly labels and assays D153V K-Ras, matching the TARGET_VARIANT. In vitro biochemical assays show normal intrinsic GTPase activity, GAP responsiveness, and nucleotide dissociation, while cellular assays reveal modest gain-of-function with elevated MAPK and mTOR signaling and hypersensitive hematopoietic colony formation. Appropriate WT and positive controls were used across multiple replicates, supporting PS3 for damaging effect. Evidence strength is moderate given well-established assays with clear comparators and known mutant controls.

Kinase assays in Cos-1 cells show that P261S increases MEK phosphorylation and constitutive ERK activation, and co-immunoprecipitation assays demonstrate loss of 14-3-3 binding. summary: The variant p.Asn308Asp (Shp2N308D) is exactly matched to the TARGET_VARIANT by protein-level notation. In NIH3T3 cells expressing Shp2N308D, EGF-stimulated Tyr705 phosphorylation of Stat3 is reduced (Fig 3B) and Stat3 DNA binding activity is diminished (Fig 3C) compared with WT controls. These results indicate a functionally abnormal effect consistent with a loss of normal Stat3 regulation. Overall, this provides PS3-level functional evidence at a supporting strength for a damaging effect of the variant.

summary: The paper explicitly presents data on the PTPN11 p.N308D variant in NS patient fibroblasts and transfected HEK293 and cardiomyocyte models (exact protein match). Assays of AKT phosphorylation, GAB1–PI3K association, in vitro phosphatase activity, GSK-3β phosphorylation, SRF-driven transcription, and ANF reporter activity all yielded results similar to wild-type SHP2. No functional perturbation was observed, and overall functional evidence is not clear for PS3 or BS3.

Functional assays in Ba/F3 cells showed increased ERK phosphorylation and cytokine-independent growth (n=3, p<0.0001), and heightened sensitivity to cobimetinib (p<0.01). summary: The paper reports the MEK2 c.383C→A (p.P128Q) mutation in a multigenerational family with cardio-facio-cutaneous syndrome, matching the TARGET_VARIANT by exact cDNA and protein notation. A functional assay in HEK293T cells using Western blot for ERK phosphorylation demonstrated that p.P128Q increases p-ERK relative to wild-type MEK2, indicating a weak hypermorphic effect. Appropriate positive and negative controls were included, supporting a damaging functional impact. These data support applying PS3 at a supporting level for this variant.

summary: The variant p.N581D (N581D) in BRAF is listed among the CFC alleles tested in zebrafish embryos (Table 1) and matched by exact protein notation with medium confidence. Injection of N581D mRNA promotes an elongated embryo phenotype (45% embryos elongated vs 0% WT), and treatment with the MEK inhibitor CI-1040 or the FGFR inhibitor SU-5402 restores normal embryo morphology, consistent with an abnormal gain-of-function effect. Based on the presence of a WT comparator and inhibitor rescue controls, the evidence supports a PS3 supportive classification for p.N581D.

summary: The paper describes a CDH1 splicing mutation c.1137G>A in family 2 (Figure 2B–C), matching the TARGET_VARIANT at the cDNA level. An RT-PCR assay in patient blood lymphocytes showed that c.1137G>A induces complex aberrant splicing with an in-frame deletion of exon 8. This functional abnormality, compared to wild type transcripts, supports a damaging effect. Overall, the evidence meets PS3 at supporting strength due to limited assay validation.

Functional assays (capillary fragment analysis and cloning/sequencing) demonstrated that the variant creates a novel 5’ splice donor site, resulting in a 32-nt deletion in exon 11 and complete loss of normal transcript. These results support PS3_moderate evidence for a damaging splicing defect consistent with disease mechanism.

summary: The c.1008G>A variant in CDH1 was matched by exact cDNA sequencing evidence in KATO-III cells. RT-PCR-SSCP analysis showed that this mutation disrupts the exon 7 splice donor site, producing four aberrant mRNA transcript species, with a predominant 7-bp insertion causing frameshift. Northern blot analysis demonstrated markedly reduced E-cadherin mRNA levels in the mutant cell line compared to wild-type controls. These results indicate a functionally abnormal outcome consistent with loss-of-function. Overall, this supports PS3_supporting evidence for the pathogenicity of the variant.

summary: The c.1008G12T variant was matched via description of a G→T transversion at nucleotide 1008 of CDH1 exon 7. Exon linking RT-PCR on stomach biopsy RNA showed mutant-specific use of a cryptic splice site producing a 7-bp insertion and premature stop codon (Fig. 2c), with 19/20 clones demonstrating the splice defect. This assay establishes a damaging splicing outcome, supporting PS3_moderate evidence for loss-of-function.

summary: The variant c.2195G>A (p.R732Q) in CDH1 is an exact match to the paper’s G2195A (R732Q). Functional assays in CHO-K1 cells demonstrate that R732Q markedly reduces cell–cell adhesion and increases invasion compared with wild type. Adequate controls and replicates were included, supporting a functionally abnormal effect. The evidence meets PS3 supporting level for pathogenic impact.

summary: The variant p.His93Arg (H93R) was directly tested in stable Tet-Off PC12 cells and matched exactly the H93R label in the paper. Western blot assays demonstrated that H93R mutant PTEN fails to suppress TH expression and AKT phosphorylation compared to wild-type PTEN. Cycloheximide chase assays revealed markedly decreased protein stability of H93R PTEN. These results indicate a loss-of-function effect consistent with PTEN-associated ASD. Overall, PS3 supporting evidence is present for a damaging impact of p.His93Arg.

summary: The paper describes the autism-associated PTEN variant p.H93R (H93R PTEN) identified by the exact amino acid substitution in a PTEN context. Multiple assays using purified protein and cellular systems show that H93R PTEN has ~15% of wild-type enzymatic activity, fails to undergo PI(4,5)P2-induced conformational activation, and exhibits altered lipid binding (decreased PI(4,5)P2 and increased PS interaction). Cell-based assays confirm reduced Akt dephosphorylation and altered plasma membrane localization. These results support classifying PS3 at moderate strength for a damaging effect consistent with PTEN loss-of-function.

summary: The PTEN variant p.H93R was matched directly in the paper by the label 'H93R'. Multiple functional assays indicate loss-of-function: in vivo neuronal soma size and pS6 rescue assays show H93R fails to rescue PTEN knockout phenotypes (p<0.001), and in vitro PIP3 mass ELISA demonstrates impaired lipid phosphatase activity. The variant shows normal subcellular localization and stability, excluding these as mechanisms of dysfunction. Overall, the evidence supports a PS3 moderate classification for p.H93R.

summary: The GJB2 p.Trp24Ter variant (W24X) was matched via exact protein label and HGVSc c.71G>A. Western blot unexpectedly shows full-length protein likely via stop codon read-through, but EGFP-fusion and immunocytochemistry reveal predominant cytoplasmic localization rather than membrane targeting. No gap junction channel assay was performed. These localization defects support PS3 at a supporting strength for loss-of-function.

summary: The c.-22-2A>C variant was matched by exact cDNA notation in the paper. Reverse-transcriptase PCR and capillary fragment analysis in saliva RNA demonstrated complete loss of the canonical acceptor site with activation of two alternative sites, and RT-qPCR quantified a marked reduction of canonical transcripts to 18% of wild-type alongside increased alternative splicing. These functional studies show abnormal splicing consistent with loss-of-function, supporting application of PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The KCNQ4 p.G285S variant was assessed by perforated patch clamp electrophysiology in CHO cells. Expression of G285S yielded no measurable current, and co-expression with wild-type KCNQ4 or KCNQ5 reduced currents to ~6% of controls, demonstrating a dominant-negative loss of function. These findings support application of PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The BRAF p.F247L variant was directly engineered and tested in Ba/F3 cells both as a domain fusion and in full-length BRAF, where it drove IL3-independent proliferation (184-fold activation for fusion constructs; 116-fold for full-length), activated MAPK signaling as shown by increased ERK1/2 phosphorylation, and conferred sensitivity to dabrafenib and trametinib. Assays included positive control BRAF V600E and GFP controls, with replicates and significant p-values. These results consistently indicate a gain-of-function effect for p.F247L, supporting PS3_moderate evidence.

summary: The variant p.E139D (c.417G>C) was matched exactly by both cDNA and protein notation in the paper (status: matched, confidence: medium). In vitro phosphatase assays demonstrated dramatically enhanced catalytic activation of SHP2 E139D vs. WT (P<0.001), and SPR binding assays showed increased phosphopeptide binding affinity. Phosphopeptide array analysis revealed altered C-SH2 specificity. These gain-of-function results support PS3 (moderate) evidence for a pathogenic effect.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: In vitro enzymatic assays and cell‐based signaling assays with WT controls, replicates, and statistical analysis
overall_evidence.basis: T468M shows significantly reduced catalytic activity and disrupted autoinhibition while promoting increased Gab1 binding and sustained ERK activation, consistent with GOF disease mechanism

summary: The variant T468M was explicitly tested as one of the LEOPARD syndrome–associated SHP2 mutants. Biochemical assays show T468M has greatly reduced phosphatase activity and weakened autoinhibitory interaction, while cell‐based assays demonstrate enhanced binding to Gab1 and sustained ERK1/2 activation under both EGF and HGF stimulation. These functional abnormalities support a GOF effect consistent with LEOPARD syndrome pathogenesis. Overall evidence supports PS3_moderate for T468M.

experiments.assay: Phosphatase activity assay using pNPP substrate

experiments.readout: Phosphate release from pNPP measured by absorbance at 410 nm; fold activation with/without phosphotyrosyl peptide

result.effect_size_and_stats: T468M activity significantly reduced compared to wild-type CSW; data are means ± SD of ≥3 experiments (Figure 1)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Assay performed in triplicate; wild-type CSW and NS N308D proteins included as controls; peptide stimulation
experiments.authors_conclusion: LEOPARD syndrome CSW mutant proteins (Y279C and T468M) have reduced phosphatase activities

experiments.system: Ubiquitous expression in Drosophila melanogaster (tub-GAL4 driver)
experiments.variant_material: UAS-cswT468M transgenic flies
experiments.readout: Presence of ectopic wing veins in adult flies; percentage of wings with ectopic veins

result.effect_size_and_stats: 20% of T468M-expressing wings display ectopic veins vs 3% in wild-type CSW control (n≥40; p<0.001)

experiments.controls_and_validation: ≥3 independent transgenic lines; ≥40 wings scored per genotype; statistical analysis by χ²
experiments.authors_conclusion: Ubiquitous expression of LEOPARD syndrome alleles Y279C and T468M causes ectopic wing vein formation
caveats: T468M shows lower penetrance than Y279C, suggesting allele strength differences

experiments.assay: Eye photoreceptor specification and ommatidial rotation assay
experiments.system: Ubiquitous expression in Drosophila melanogaster (tub-GAL4 driver)

experiments.authors_conclusion: dpERK expression levels in LS Y279C- and T468M-expressing larvae are significantly increased
caveats: Immunostaining in embryos showed no pattern differences (data not shown)

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Multiple independent assays with wild-type controls, replicates, and statistical analysis demonstrating consistent abnormal activity
overall_evidence.basis: T468M shows reduced phosphatase activity in vitro and gain-of-function developmental phenotypes with increased MAPK signaling compared to wild-type comparator in Drosophila model; direct protein match supports damaging functional impact

summary: The human PTPN11 p.T468M variant is directly modeled by the cswT468M transgene in Drosophila (matched via exact protein change). Biochemical assays show that CSW T468M has significantly reduced phosphatase activity, whereas developmental assays reveal GOF phenotypes including ectopic wing veins and elevated dpERK levels in larvae, though no effect on eye photoreceptor patterning. These results provide PS3 moderate evidence for a damaging, gain-of-function effect of the p.T468M variant.

summary: The variant p.Tyr63Cys in PTPN11 was matched by exact protein notation across the paper. Purified SHP2Cys63 exhibits increased basal and BTAM-stimulated phosphatase activity and enhances ERK phosphorylation in cells, while maintaining normal phosphopeptide-binding affinity and specificity. These consistent gain-of-function findings support a PS3_moderate classification for p.Tyr63Cys.

experiments.variant_material: Synthetic double-stranded oligonucleotide probe containing FBS1 (wild-type or c.103T>C) and in vitro–translated FOXI1 protein
experiments.readout: Intensity of shifted probe band (cpm) quantified by competition assay

result.effect_size_and_stats: At 100× unlabeled competitor, shift band intensity drops to 0.12-fold with wild-type competitor versus 0.56-fold with mutant competitor

experiments.controls_and_validation: Competition with unlabeled wild-type and mutant probes at 10–100× molar excess; poly d(I-C) in binding buffer; quantification by AlphaEaseFC
experiments.authors_conclusion: c.103T>C mutation significantly reduces FOXI1 binding to FBS1

experiments.variant_material: 250 ng pGL3 reporter with 5 kb SLC26A4 promoter (wild-type or c.103T>C) and 750 ng FOXI1 or empty vector
experiments.readout: Luciferase activity (fold induction normalized to total protein)

result.effect_size_and_stats: Mutant promoter shows ~1-fold induction versus ~6-fold for wild-type (mean±SD, n≥3; P<0.001)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Empty vector control; promoter deletion and inversion constructs; triplicate experiments; normalization to protein
experiments.authors_conclusion: c.103T>C abolishes FOXI1-mediated transcriptional activation of SLC26A4

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Well-established EMSA and luciferase assays with replicates, competition controls, normalization, and statistical significance reported
overall_evidence.basis: Functional assays show reduced FOXI1 binding and loss of transcriptional activation for the c.-103T>C promoter mutation, consistent with loss-of-function disease mechanism, with high confidence in variant matching

summary: The paper identifies the SLC26A4 promoter variant c.103TrC (equivalent to HGVSc c.-103T>C, rs60284988) and shows by EMSA that FOXI1 binding to FBS1 is significantly reduced and by luciferase reporter assay in COS-7 cells that FOXI1-mediated transcriptional activation is abolished. These well-controlled functional assays demonstrate a damaging effect consistent with loss of SLC26A4 expression, supporting application of PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The PTEN p.M35R variant was directly matched by protein notation in the paper. In a yeast PIP3 phosphatase assay, M35R failed to rescue growth and exhibited persistent GFP-Akt1 plasma membrane localization, indicating loss of enzymatic activity. Immunofluorescence in COS-7 cells revealed increased nuclear accumulation compared to wild-type. These findings support PS3 at a supporting level for the damaging effect of p.M35R.

summary: The paper engineers the equivalent p.Cys282Arg (C282R) mutation in human SOS1, matching the target variant. In EGF-stimulated NIH 3T3 and HEK 293 EBNA cells, hSOS1 C282R increases MAPK phosphorylation relative to wild type in multiple independent experiments. This provides PS3 supporting evidence for a functionally abnormal effect of p.Cys282Arg consistent with disease mechanism.

summary: The SLC26A4 c.147C>G (p.Ser49Arg) variant was matched by identical HGVS cDNA and protein notation in Table 1. Functional HCO3–/Cl– and I–/Cl– antiport assays in HEK293T stable cell lines showed transport activities indistinguishable from wild-type (F-test p=0.78 and p=0.29, respectively). These well-controlled, replicated assays support a BS3_moderate classification, indicating the variant is functionally normal.

summary: The TP53 p.A347D variant is directly matched in this paper as p53(A347D). Multiple endogenous assays in CRISPR‐edited U2OS cells and patient fibroblasts demonstrate that p53(A347D) is hyperstable, fails to tetramerize, and cannot transactivate canonical p53 targets, consistent with a loss‐of‐function. Additional assays show aberrant mitochondrial morphology, metabolic reprogramming, and increased apoptosis under genotoxic stress. These well‐controlled functional studies support a PS3_moderate classification for the p.A347D variant.

summary: The variant p.C282Y (c.845G>A) in SLC26A4 is strictly matched by protein and cDNA labels in tables and figures. In HEK293 Phoenix cells, the iodide influx assay reveals ∼41% of wild-type transport activity (p<0.001). Confocal imaging shows efficient plasma membrane localization but a significant reduction in total and membrane-specific expression levels (p<0.01). Western blot of membrane fractions confirms reduced pendrin abundance (~0.6 of wild-type, p<0.01). These consistent functionally abnormal findings support a PS3 moderate classification.

summary: The BRAF p.Thr599Arg variant (c.1796C>G) was matched with medium confidence via exact cDNA and protein labels in Table 1 and Methods, and applied in functional assays (Fig 3A,B). In NIH-3T3 focus formation and HEK293 phosphorylation assays, p.Thr599Arg showed increased foci formation and enhanced MEK/ERK phosphorylation compared to wild type, though less than the oncogenic p.Val600Glu control. Well-established assays with positive and negative controls across replicates support a gain-of-function effect. These data provide PS3_moderate evidence for a damaging effect of p.Thr599Arg.

summary: The c.2238G>A (p.Trp746X) variant is directly matched by exact cDNA and protein change in the paper. Western blot analyses on patient fibroblast homogenates using both polyclonal and monoclonal anti-GAA antibodies show no detectable GAA protein versus normal controls, indicating a CRIM-negative status. The assay included appropriate positive and negative controls with beta-actin loading control. Overall, this supports PS3 (moderate) for this variant.

summary: The paper directly tests BRAF p.V471F, matching the TARGET_VARIANT by exact protein change. In vitro kinase assays show V471F is kinase-dead, while cellular ERK assays and activator/receiver dimerization assays demonstrate that V471F promotes ERK activation via allosteric mechanisms requiring dimerization. Basic controls against WT and known mutants were included but no statistical analysis was provided. These data support applying PS3 at a supporting level for this variant.

summary: The MAP2K1 c.370C>T (p.Pro124Ser) variant is explicitly reported and assayed in the paper. MAP2K1P124S induces ERK1/2 phosphorylation in HEK293T cells, transforms NIH3T3 cells, and confers increased resistance to the MEK inhibitor AZD6244 in melanoma cells. These results constitute PS3-level functional evidence at moderate strength for a damaging gain-of-function effect.

summary: The variant p.L214P (c.641T>C) is reported in Table 3 and studied in patient MM. Flow cytometry shows <1% αIIbβ3 expression and <1% PAC-1 binding after activation, and light transmission aggregometry demonstrates absent aggregation with ADP and collagen compared to WT controls. These functional assays indicate a damaging effect on integrin αIIbβ3 consistent with Glanzmann thrombasthenia. Overall, strong functional evidence supports PS3 at a moderate strength level.

summary: The paper reports ITGB3 c.565C>T (p.Pro189Ser, P163S) confirmed by sequencing. In CHO cell transfection assays, flow cytometry shows P163S markedly reduces aIIbb3 surface expression (2% vs 18% of WT) and decreases intracellular b3 (12% vs 18%), whereas avb3 surface expression remains near normal (22% vs 28%). These results indicate a deleterious effect on aIIbb3 consistent with the Glanzmann thrombasthenia mechanism. Overall, this supports PS3 at a supporting level.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT p.P176H was matched to 'αIIb P176H' in the paper with medium confidence via exact protein nomenclature. In HEK293 cells expressing P176H, immunoblot analysis demonstrated dramatically reduced proαIIb and virtually no mature αIIb, and flow cytometry showed surface expression reduced from ~40% (WT) to ~3%. summary: We heuristically matched the human p.Gly341Arg to the rabbit G342R mutation studied. In HEK293 cell assays, G342R increased caffeine sensitivity, elevated resting cytoplasmic Ca2+, and depleted ER luminal Ca2+, while microsomal [3H]ryanodine binding assays demonstrated marked increases in channel gain and Ca2+ sensitivity at both 25°C and 37°C. These functionally abnormal results support a PS3_moderate classification for the target variant.

summary: The paper reports studies on Y522S-RYR1 knock-in mice (referred to as YS or RYR1Y524S) corresponding to the human p.Tyr522Ser variant. In FDB fibers from YS mice, Fura-2 assays show elevated resting and stimulated cytosolic Ca2+; ER-D1 cameleon reveals greater SR Ca2+ depletion; mitochondrial cameleon shows increased matrix Ca2+ uptake; and MitoSOX assays demonstrate heightened mitochondrial ROS. Together, these well-controlled assays provide supporting PS3 evidence for a damaging gain-of-function effect of the Y522S variant.

summary: The paper examines rabbit RYR1 R402H (human R401H) in HEK293 Ca2+ imaging assays. R402H exhibited increased caffeine sensitivity, elevated resting cytosolic Ca2+, and reduced ER Ca2+ stores compared to WT, consistent with a gain-of-function effect underlying malignant hyperthermia. summary: The CDH1 c.715G>A (p.Gly239Arg) variant was matched exactly by cDNA and protein notation throughout the paper. RT-PCR followed by TOPO cloning and sequencing of patient-derived blood RNA showed that 53 of 99 clones contained a 29 bp deletion in exon 6, leading to premature truncation, with only 1 of 99 clones retaining a full-length mutant transcript. This functional evidence demonstrates a loss-of-function effect consistent with pathogenicity. According to ACMG/AMP guidelines, these results support PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The variant c.1057G>A was matched by exact cDNA notation in the positive control cohort and assessed by capture RNA-seq. The assay measured an exon skipping event r.1055_1137del with a PSI of 33%, significantly above the control mean (p<1×10^{-55}), confirming abnormal splicing. This functional effect is consistent with CDH1 loss-of-function. Accordingly, PS3_supporting is assigned based on these splicing results.

summary: We matched the TARGET_VARIANT p.Arg163Trp to the paper’s ETHE1-p.Arg163Trp protein change, explicitly reported in the title, abstract, figures, and tables. Comparison of CD spectra shows the variant maintains native fold, but thermal denaturation and limited proteolysis reveal significant destabilization. Enzymatic oxygen consumption assays demonstrate <10% of wild-type activity, and redox titration by EPR shows a 100 mV lower Fe-site reduction potential. These results indicate loss-of-function consistent with the disease mechanism. We apply PS3_moderate for the functional evidence.

overall_evidence.basis: Cell-based and in vitro kinase assays demonstrate severe reduction in MAP1S and CEP131 phosphorylation by I72T compared to WT CDKL5, consistent with disease mechanism and explicit variant testing.

summary: The CDKL5 p.Ile72Thr (c.215T>C) variant is explicitly tested in Muñoz et al. Functional assays in HEK293 cells show that co-expression of I72T CDKL5 with MAP1S or CEP131 results in severely reduced phosphorylation of MAP1S Ser900 and CEP131 Ser35 relative to WT. In vitro kinase assays using synthetic peptides confirm near-zero activity of I72T CDKL5 toward both substrates compared to WT. These data demonstrate that p.Ile72Thr causes loss of kinase function, supporting PS3_moderate evidence for pathogenicity.

summary: The variant p.Val859Met (c.2575G>A) was matched by exact cDNA and protein notation in multiple sections of the paper. In CHO-ldlA7 cells, p.Val859Met exhibited LDL uptake, degradation, binding, cell surface expression, and subcellular localization indistinguishable from wild-type LDLR across multiple assays. These data support BS3 at a supporting level, as p.Val859Met shows normal function relative to WT using appropriate controls and replicates.

summary: The LDLR variant p.(His656Asn) was strictly matched by both c.1966C>A and p.(His656Asn) in Table 1. In CHO-ldlA7 cells, Western blot and flow cytometry assays show expression at levels comparable to wild-type. LDL binding and uptake measured by FACS are indistinguishable from wild-type. These well-controlled, replicated functional assays support a BS3 call at moderate strength for p.(His656Asn).

Functional assays using DiI-LDL uptake in EBV-transformed B-lymphocytes and ionomycin+PMA-stimulated T-lymphocytes show decreased residual LDLR activity (38.9–73.2% of control), indicating functionally abnormal effect. summary: The LDLR p.Trp87Gly variant (c.259T>G) was directly matched by cDNA and protein notation in patients 1 and 2. Functional assays in lymphocytes and CHO-ldlA7 cells demonstrate that p.Trp87Gly is expressed at normal levels but exhibits markedly reduced LDL binding and uptake (~10% of wild-type), consistent with a class 3 loss-of-function mutation. Assays were well controlled with wild-type and null variant controls, performed in triplicate, and analyzed statistically. These results support a PS3 moderate evidence classification for p.Trp87Gly.

summary: The variant p.(Asp47Asn) (c.139G>A) in LDLR was explicitly tested in CHO-ldlA7 cells via Western blot and flow cytometry assays for cell surface expression, LDL binding, and uptake. In all four independent assays with WT comparators and internal null controls, p.(Asp47Asn) activity was comparable to WT (n=3, no significant differences). These results support BS3 with moderate strength, indicating a functionally normal, likely benign impact of this variant.

summary: The LDLR variant c.1A>T (p.Met1Leu) was directly matched in the paper. In CHO-ldlA7 cells, Western blotting showed near absence of mature and precursor LDLR, flow cytometry demonstrated <10% surface expression, LDL binding, and internalization relative to WT, and luciferase reporter assays indicated ~0.5% translation initiation efficiency. All assays used WT and mock controls with significant p-values (p<0.001). These data demonstrate a loss-of-function effect consistent with PS3_supporting evidence.

summary: The paper describes a 13-bp deletion at the intron 3–exon 4 junction of ITGA2B (c.409-2_419del), matching the TARGET_VARIANT. Functional studies in BHK cells transfected with the deletion and wild-type β3 show complete loss of αIIbβ3 surface expression and fibrinogen binding, and immunoblotting reveals absence of mature αIIb. These data support a damaging loss-of-function effect, fulfilling PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The paper reports the GAA protein variant Asp-645->Glu by exact protein-level matches. Site-directed mutagenesis and expression in COS cells demonstrated that the Asp-645->Glu mutant has severely reduced enzymatic activity (~2–3% of wild-type), delayed proteolytic processing, deficient phosphorylation, and retention in the endoplasmic reticulum with reduced lysosomal delivery. These findings are consistent with a GAA loss-of-function mechanism. The functional data support PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The variant chrM_8993_T_G corresponds exactly to the nt 8993 T->G substitution described. Polarographic assays of mitochondria from patient lymphoblasts homoplasmic for the mutation showed 26–50% reductions in state III respiration and 30–40% decreases in ADP/O ratios relative to controls, with uncoupled respiration intact. Transmitochondrial cybrids homoplasmic for the nt 8993 T->G mutation recapitulated these defects (state III respiration reduced 24–53% and ADP/O by ~30%), whereas wild-type cybrids were normal. These well-controlled functional data support a damaging effect of the variant (PS3, moderate).

summary: The mitochondrial m.8993T>G (T8993G) variant was matched by exact genomic coordinate and cDNA notation in the ATP6 gene. Patient-derived homoplasmic cybrid lines harboring T8993G exhibited significantly reduced ATP synthesis, impaired coupled and uncoupled respiration, variable complex I and IV enzymatic activities, defective assembly of respiratory chain complexes, and severe growth defects in galactose medium. These results consistently demonstrate a damaging effect on oxidative phosphorylation versus WT comparators, supporting a PS3_moderate functional evidence classification.

summary: The paper reports the AKT3 E17K (c.49G>A, p.Glu17Lys) mutation in melanoma and confirms it by Sanger sequencing. Transient expression of HA-AKT3 E17K in A375 cells increases AKT phosphorylation relative to wildtype and empty vector (Figure 1C). The use of WT and empty vector controls without quantitative statistics provides basic validation. Across Ba/F3 IL3-independent survival, MCF10A growth factor-free proliferation, soft agar colony formation, and pooled in vivo tumorigenesis assays, the I31M variant showed no functional activity compared to WT and known pathogenic controls. summary: The MTOR p.S2215Y variant is explicitly reported in the paper (S2215Y) and matches the TARGET_VARIANT. Multiple functional assays in HEK293T cells demonstrate that S2215Y confers constitutive mTORC1 activation (increased phosphorylation of S6K1 and 4E-BP1 in vivo and in vitro), promotes cell-cycle progression and cell-size maintenance under starvation, while mTORC2 activity remains unchanged. The variant maintains sensitivity to rapamycin but shows resistance to phospholipase D inhibition. Overall, PS3_moderate evidence supports a pathogenic gain-of-function effect for S2215Y.

summary: The variant p.H1047R (H1047R) in PIK3CA matches the TARGET_VARIANT exactly. In growth-factor independent viability assays in Ba/F3 and MCF10A cells, H1047R exhibited strong activating effects relative to wild-type, reproducibly active in 95–98% and 77–88% of replicates, respectively. These assays included negative controls (GFP, mCherry) and positive controls (WT PIK3CA, M1043I) across multiple independent experiments. This supports PS3_moderate evidence for a gain-of-function effect.

summary: The HNF1A variant c.392G>A (p.Arg131Gln, rs753998395) is explicitly reported in the paper and confidently matched. Functional assays demonstrate that p.Arg131Gln has normal protein abundance but shows significantly reduced nuclear localization (<50% vs >60% WT) and impaired DNA-binding ability (<50% of WT). Transactivation assays were performed but specific activities were not detailed. Together, the orthogonal evidence supports a damaging effect consistent with PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The c.546G>T variant was directly matched by its cDNA notation and demonstrated aberrant splicing in patient fibroblasts, including exon 2 skipping and intron 1 inclusion with reduced mRNA levels. Cycloheximide treatment revealed activation of a cryptic splice donor at c.546+184 causing intron retention and NMD. Antisense oligonucleotide rescue restored canonical splicing and increased GAA enzymatic activity. These data provide PS3_moderate functional evidence supporting a damaging effect of c.546G>T.

summary: The HNF1A variant p.P447L (c.1340C>T) was matched via its exact protein change and cDNA notation in Table 1 and Figure 2. In a luciferase reporter assay in HeLa cells, p.P447L showed severely reduced transactivation, �320% of wild-type activity across nine readings with 95% CIs, indicating a loss-of-function effect. The assay was validated with wild-type and known MODY3 controls and internal normalization. Based on this functionally abnormal result in a validated assay, PS3_moderate evidence is assigned.

summary: The paper reports functional characterization of HNF1A p.P447L (exact match to TARGET_VARIANT). P447L exhibits reduced DNA binding and partial loss-of-function on an artificial HP1-tk luciferase reporter, though activity normalizes at higher expression and on a native HNF4 promoter. The mutant retains heterodimerization with wild type and shows no dominant negative effect. Overall, these data support a partial loss-of-function consistent with haploinsufficiency, fulfilling PS3_supporting criteria.

summary: The paper reports the human c.14510delA mutation (R4837fsX4839), matching the target c.14510delA. Functional assays in HEK293 cells and dyspedic mouse myotubes demonstrate that the truncated RyR1 is non-functional when expressed alone, alters heterotetrameric channel sensitivity, and fails to support Ca2+ release while WT comparator controls are included. These results provide moderate-level PS3 evidence supporting a damaging effect of the variant.

summary: The paper precisely identifies the variant R2849P (c.8546G>C) in ATM (Table 1, Figs 2b and 3b). In AT1ABR A-T cells, R2849P fails to restore ATM kinase activity and does not correct radiation-induced chromosome instability, while in C3ABR control cells it abolishes endogenous ATM kinase activation and increases aberrations. These consistent loss-of-function findings support a PS3 classification with moderate strength.

summary: The paper reports c.811C>T (p.Arg271Trp) in HNF1A, matching the TARGET_VARIANT exactly. Functional studies in both Cos7 and Min6 cells demonstrate that this variant severely impairs transcriptional activation of GLUT2, β-fibrinogen, HNF4A P2, and insulin promoters. EMSA binding titrations and nuclear extract assays show significantly reduced DNA binding affinity and capacity for both consensus and HNF-4α P2 probes. These consistent loss-of-function results support a PS3 moderate evidence classification.

summary: The paper models the human mtDNA T9176C mutation (c.T9176C) as yeast atp6-L247P, matched by explicit cDNA change and protein residue equivalence. Yeast mitochondria bearing this variant show a ~30% reduction in ATP synthesis, ~25% reduced ATPase with altered oligomycin sensitivity, normal proton pumping, and reduced complex stability. These well-controlled enzymatic and assembly assays support a damaging effect consistent with PS3 evidence, assigned at moderate strength.

summary: FOXG1G224S (c.670G>A, p.Gly224Ser) is explicitly tested in multiple functional assays in murine neural cultures, including neuron differentiation (Figure 2), dendritic arborization (Figure 3), neuronal activity (Figure 4), transcript regulation (Figure 5), glial fate choice (Figure 6), proliferation of astrocyte and oligodendrocyte progenitors (Figures 6 and 8), and glial gene expression (Figure 7). The variant consistently shows functionally abnormal effects (predominantly gain-of-function) relative to Plap controls and exceeding FOXG1WT effects. However, these alterations contradict the known FOXG1 loss-of-function disease mechanism, rendering the PS3/BS3 criteria not clearly applicable.

summary: The mitochondrial ATP6 G8969>A variant (chrM_8969_G_A) was directly identified in the paper and matched with high confidence. In human cybrid cells, increasing loads of G8969>A caused abnormal mitochondrial morphology, reduced oxygen consumption (BR, OSR, MR), and increased ROS production versus WT. In yeast homoplasmic for the equivalent atp6-S175N mutation, cells failed to grow on glycerol, and isolated mitochondria exhibited ~90% reductions in respiration and ATP synthesis, impaired membrane potential changes, and defective ATP synthase assembly. These consistent functional abnormalities support a PS3_moderate classification for G8969>A.

overall_evidence.basis: D213GH variant shows intact assembly but decreased electron transfer (46–72% of WT) and reduced proton pumping (33–70% of WT) with slowed kinetics, consistent with damaging loss-of-function; mapping to human D199G via explicit alignment

summary: The paper models the human m.3902-3908inv7 MT-ND1 mutation by introducing the equivalent D213G variant in E. coli complex I (corresponding to human D199G). In multiple assays, D213G assembles into a stable complex but shows a 28–54% reduction in electron transfer activity, prominent lag-phases in quinone reduction, and 30–70% of WT proton pumping. Well-controlled and replicated biochemical assays thus demonstrate a damaging functional effect. On this basis, PS3 evidence is applied at moderate strength.

summary: The LDLR variant c.530C>T was matched exactly by the paper’s description of a C-to-T transition at nucleotide 530 leading to Ser156Leu (equivalent to Ser177Leu). Functional assays in patient fibroblasts show that the mutant receptor displays markedly delayed processing, absent LDL binding, reduced internalization and degradation, while retaining β-VLDL binding. Heterozygous cells exhibit partial function at ~40% of normal. These consistent loss-of-function results support a PS3 supportive-level classification.

summary: The variant p.L881P in DICER1 was matched to the paper’s p.L881P label by exact protein and cDNA notation. In vitro cleavage assays and EMSA demonstrated severe loss of pre-miRNA processing and binding by the L881P protein. In Dicer1−/− MSCs, L881P failed to rescue global miRNA levels and miRNA-mediated silencing in luciferase reporters. These consistent functional deficits support a PS3 moderate classification for p.L881P.

overall_evidence.basis: Multiple independent functional assays show R2509C (human p.R2508C) causes abnormal Ca2+ handling and contracture versus WT, consistent with MH hyperactivation; mapping uncertainty medium

summary: The human RYR1 p.Arg2508Cys variant was matched to the mouse RYR1-p.R2509C mutation based on explicit correspondence in the paper. In isolated R2509C FDB cells, elevated resting and anesthetic-induced Ca2+ release and enhanced caffeine- and heat-induced contracture were demonstrated, with sarcolemmal cation influx unaltered. These gain-of-function assays consistently show a damaging effect of the variant. PS3 applies at moderate strength given well-controlled comparisons and replication.
