summary: This paper specifically studies the p.Thr4826Ile (T4826I) RYR1 variant, clearly matching protein-level notation. In FDB fibers and in vivo microelectrode recordings, T4826I-RYR1 shows elevated resting and evoked Ca2+ signals and heightened sensitivity to halothane. In myotubes, the variant impairs mitochondrial respiration, reduces mitochondrial content, and elevates calpain activity. Biophysical assays reveal increased channel open probability, altered Ca2+/Mg2+ regulation, and enhanced temperature sensitivity. These consistent functional abnormalities support PS3_moderate evidence for a damaging effect.

summary: The paper investigates a knock-in mouse expressing the murine p.G2435R variant, explicitly stated as iso-genetic with human p.G2434R. Functional assays in primary myotubes show increased Ca2+ release sensitivity to caffeine, KCl, and halothane versus wild-type. Intact mice exhibit fulminant heat- and halothane-induced MH phenotype, and in vivo muscle fibers display elevated resting and anesthetic-induced intracellular Ca2+ and Na+ levels. These results support PS3 at a moderate strength for the TARGET_VARIANT.

summary: The variant m.13094T>C was directly matched to the patient’s heteroplasmic mutation in MT-ND5 (chrM_13094_T_C). Functional assays in patient fibroblasts and transmitochondrial cybrids consistently showed decreased oxygen consumption, ATP production, complex I and V activity, reduced mtDNA copy number, and increased autophagy relative to WT controls. These well-established assays with clear WT comparators support a deleterious effect on complex I function. Overall, there is PS3 moderate evidence for pathogenicity under ACMG criteria.

summary: The paper describes an engineered mouse allele T4709M (TM), explicitly matching human p.Thr4709Met. Heterozygous Ryr1WT/TM mice show normal Ryr1 transcript and protein levels, while compound Ryr1TM/Indel mice exhibit significantly reduced ex vivo EDL muscle force generation and attenuated Ca²⁺ release in isolated FDB fibres. Overall, these functional studies provide moderate-level PS3 evidence supporting a damaging, loss-of-function effect of the p.Thr4709Met variant.

summary: The paper reports the c.953T>C (p.Met318Thr) variant in GAA, identified by sequencing of PCR-amplified cDNA and genomic analysis. Allele-specific PCR–RFLP showed >95% mRNA expression from the mutant allele. Transient transfection of a hybrid minigene carrying the T953-to-C mutation into GAA-deficient cells resulted in negligible enzyme activity compared to WT. This functional evidence supports a damaging effect consistent with PS3, at a supporting strength.

summary: The paper uses exact cDNA and protein notation c.65C>A; p.Ser22* to study the TARGET_VARIANT. Patient-derived MSCs and CRISPR-modified Hs27 cells exhibit significantly reduced metabolic activity, proliferation, wound healing, and glucose uptake, with normal GLUT1 expression, along with abnormal mitochondrial ultrastructure and altered proteomic profiles. These results demonstrate consistent loss-of-function effects of the c.65C>A variant across multiple functional assays. Therefore, PS3 functional evidence supporting a damaging effect is moderate strength.

summary: The paper strictly investigates the mitochondrial 12S rRNA C1494T mutation (matched by genomic position chrM_1494_C_T with high confidence). Homoplasmic cybrid cell lines carrying C1494T exhibit a ~40% decrease in mitochondrial protein synthesis, ~35–47% reduction in endogenous and substrate-driven respiration, and ~30% increased sensitivity to paromomycin compared to wild-type cybrids. Well-controlled assays with replicates and positive controls indicate functionally abnormal outcomes consistent with a pathogenic mechanism, supporting a PS3_moderate classification.

summary: The variant c.1509+16A>G (g.95117606T>C, rs201947254) was strictly matched by HGVSc to the intronic DICER1 variant studied. A tumor RNA RT-PCR splicing assay (Fig 4D) demonstrated aberrant inclusion of intronic sequence relative to a WT control, consistent with loss-of-function. We apply PS3 supportive evidence strength for this functional splicing assay.

overall_evidence.basis: c.475G>A (G128S) shows consistent defects in maturation and trafficking of αIIbβ3 in multiple assays in HEK293 cells, consistent with disease mechanism

summary: The variant c.475G>A matches the paper’s G128S mutation (medium confidence, cDNA match). In HEK293 cells, G128S αIIbβ3 forms pro-αIIb and complexes with β3 but fails to process to mature αIIb, is retained in the ER with no Golgi trafficking or surface expression. These results support a damaging effect on integrin biogenesis consistent with PS3 at the supporting level.

summary: The study directly assesses the mt-tRNALeu(UUR) 3302A>G mutation in transmitochondrial cybrid cells. Cybrids harboring 98% mutant mtDNA exhibit severe mitochondrial dysfunction, including a ~6-fold reduction in oxygen consumption, markedly decreased Complex III/IV activities, reduced tRNALeu levels, impaired aminoacylation, and increased stability of the RNA19 precursor, while tRNA stability is unchanged. These results demonstrate a pathogenic loss-of-function consistent with the disease mechanism, supporting PS3 at a moderate strength.

summary: The paper reports a high‐confidence genomic match of the TARGET_VARIANT as the mitochondrial G12276A mutation. Northern blot analysis shows a 50% reduction of tRNALeu(CUN) in patient muscle, and single‐fibre COX/SDH histochemistry correlates >80% heteroplasmy with severe COX deficiency. Bulk spectrophotometric assays further confirm decreased respiratory chain activity. These consistent functional abnormalities support a PS3 call with moderate strength.

summary: The paper lists G4298A among pathogenic mitochondrial tRNAIle mutations, matching the TARGET_VARIANT by exact nucleotide change. No 3¢-tRNase processing assays, kinetic analyses, or structure probing are presented specifically for G4298A (data not shown). Therefore, there is no functional evidence for or against an effect of G4298A from this study, and PS3/BS3 cannot be applied (not_clear).

summary: The DICER1 c.2523A>G variant (p.Q841Q) was matched via exact cDNA notation. RNA sequencing of blood-derived RNA showed that a minority of transcripts utilized a novel splice acceptor site leading to an in-frame deletion of 29 amino acids, and manual reanalysis of raw data confirmed underrepresentation of correctly spliced transcripts by allele-specific expression. These functional data support abnormal splicing and a damaging effect on DICER1, yielding a PS3 moderate level of evidence.

summary: The DICER1 variant c.2523A>G (NC_000014.8:g.95574344T>C) was matched by exact cDNA and genomic coordinates in Table 1 and Figure 1C. RNA-seq of patient blood revealed aberrant splicing with 9 of 12 reads from the variant allele mis-spliced, representing at least 12% of total transcripts. Controls included healthy reference data and a 3'UTR polymorphism confirming equal allelic representation. These data support a damaging effect via altered splicing, consistent with a loss-of-function disease mechanism. PS3_supporting is assigned.

In GAA-deficient fibroblasts, the mutant showed no detectable enzyme activity compared to WT and accumulated as the inactive precursor in Western blot. These results support PS3_supporting for a damaging functional effect.

summary: The variant c.619C>T (p.R207W) was directly matched in the paper by reporting of the cDNA and protein change in patient 1. Patient-derived fibroblasts exhibited <10% of normal creatine uptake, and HeLa cells expressing R207W showed significantly reduced transport compared to WT SLC6A8 (ANOVA p<0.01). Both assays used appropriate controls, replication, and statistical analysis. These consistent loss-of-function results support applying PS3 at a moderate strength.

summary: The mitochondrial variant chrM_1630_A_G (m.1630A>G) in MTTV is matched with high confidence by genomic coordinate in this study. Cybrid cell assays demonstrate impaired oxygen consumption and decreased activities of respiratory complexes I and IV, consistent tRNA instability shown by Northern blot, and reduced ETC protein levels by Western blot. These results indicate a functionally abnormal effect consistent with a pathogenic loss-of-function mechanism. The evidence meets PS3 at a moderate strength level due to well-established assays, replication, and clear WT comparators.

summary: The paper reports the APC variant c.835-8A>G, matching the target HGVSc exactly. RT-PCR and sequencing of patient-derived cDNA demonstrate that the variant creates a novel splice acceptor site, leading to a seven-nucleotide insertion, frameshift, and premature stop. This assay shows a functionally abnormal splicing defect. Based on these results with a wild type comparator and sequencing validation, PS3_supporting evidence is assigned for a damaging, loss-of-function effect.

summary: The variant c.391G>C (p.Gly131Arg) in GAMT was matched exactly by cDNA analysis in Figure 2. RT-PCR and sequencing of patient-derived cDNA revealed two aberrant splice products resulting in frameshifts and premature stop codons, and allele-specific expression indicated degradation of the mutant transcript by nonsense-mediated decay. These functional assays demonstrate a damaging effect consistent with loss-of-function of GAMT. On this basis, a PS3_supporting level of evidence is assigned.

Baseline assays demonstrate increased ROS production, decreased viability, and reduced respiratory capacity compared to control cells. summary: The paper describes LDLR variant c.665G>T (C201F) which corresponds to the target variant p.Cys222Phe (rs730882086) after accounting for signal peptide numbering. Localization by confocal microscopy shows ER retention, and western blot confirms impaired maturation of C201F LDLR. Flow cytometry demonstrates markedly reduced surface expression (33.2% of WT) and LDL internalization (33.5% of WT). Collectively, these well-controlled cellular assays support PS3 at moderate strength for a damaging effect of this variant.

summary: The paper explicitly studies the mitochondrial ND1 m.3460G>A (chrM_3460_G_A) variant via mito-targeted AAV delivery to mouse retinal ganglion cells. Variants labeled as hND1/m.3460G>A or mutant ND1 are matched at high confidence. Functional assays show that while the mutant protein assembles into complex I, it significantly reduces complex I activity (0.06 ± 0.05 vs 0.17 ± 0.06 OD450/min/mg, p<0.001) and ATP synthesis (325 ± 192 vs 623 ± 153 nmol/min/mg, p<0.05), and causes progressive RGC dysfunction and degeneration. These results support PS3_moderate evidence for a damaging effect of m.3460G>A on ND1 function.

summary: The paper studies the MYOC p.Asn450Tyr (N450Y) variant, a strict protein-match to the TARGET_VARIANT. In human TM cells, the N450Y mutant fails to secrete, accumulates in the ER inducing ER stress, activates autophagy, reduces viability, and increases apoptosis relative to WT. In Tg-MYOCN450Y mice, the mutant shows absent secretion into aqueous humor and elevated ER stress and autophagy markers in ocular tissues. These functional abnormalities provide moderate-level PS3 evidence supporting a damaging effect of the N450Y variant.

VLCAD enzyme activity assays in lymphocytes and fibroblasts from a patient carrying this variant demonstrated markedly reduced activity relative to reference ranges, consistent with a damaging effect. summary: The variant c.865G>A (p.G289R) is reported in Table 1 as c.G865A (p.G289R) and also labelled G289R in the prokaryotic expression study. A prokaryotic ETF fluorescence reduction assay (Figure 3) of the G289R mutant showed VLCAD activity reduced to 15% of wild-type and decreased protein stability. This functional evidence demonstrates a damaging effect consistent with VLCAD deficiency. PS3_supporting is applied based on these results.

Kinetic assays demonstrated minimal loss of enzymatic activity relative to WT, while thermal denaturation assays revealed markedly reduced protein stability. Given the clear abnormality in thermostability with an appropriate comparator and controls, this supports a PS3_moderate functional evidence for damaging effect.

summary: The variant p.E300K in GCK is directly matched by the label HIGK-E300K in the paper. In β-HC9 cell extracts, E300K exhibits a tenfold reduction in glucokinase activity despite normal glucose affinity, and in insulin-release assays shows minimal secretion above mock compared with wild-type. These findings demonstrate a damaging effect consistent with MODY-2, providing PS3_supporting evidence.

summary: The paper directly tests GCK p.G261R (G261R) in purified recombinant glucokinase enzyme assays. Compared with WT, the mutant exhibits severely reduced activity (e.g. S0.5 ~68.6 vs 7.6 mmol/l; Kcat ~17 vs 62 sec−1) in three independent experiments. Based on these clear functional abnormalities in a validated assay with WT controls, PS3_moderate is applied for this variant.

summary: The paper reports a 6-bp insertion in ITGA2B resulting in an Arg-Thr insertion between residues 160 and 161 (KO mutant aIIbb3), matching the TARGET_VARIANT c.575_576insGACAAG. Functional assays in patient platelets and recombinant 293 cells demonstrate abolished binding of ligand-mimetic antibodies OP-G2 and PAC-1, loss of fibrinogen binding after activation, and altered LIBS epitope induction, confirming a damaging effect on integrin aIIbb3. Well-controlled experiments with wild-type comparators support PS3 at the supporting level.

summary: The paper reports the SERPINC1 c.1315C>A (p.Pro439Thr) variant identified by sequencing. Recombinant 439Thr-AT expressed in HEK293 cells demonstrated reduced secretion (74% of WT) and mildly decreased progressive and heparin cofactor activities (84% and 83% of WT; n=3), while heparin affinity remained normal. These well‐controlled assays support a deleterious effect (PS3_moderate).

summary: We identified the variant c.135-1G>T in BRCA1 (rs80358158) by exact cDNA notation in the exon 3 saturation editing map. In HAP1-Lig4KO cells, this canonical splice acceptor SNV was markedly depleted in a cell survival–based SGE assay (function score < –1.25) and exhibited reduced RNA abundance. These results indicate a disruptive effect on splicing and BRCA1 function. On this basis, PS3_moderate evidence supports a damaging impact consistent with a loss-of-function mechanism.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT c.7879A>T (p.Ile2627Phe) is listed in Table 1 as a class 4/5 variant with exact cDNA and protein notation matching the TARGET. In a mouse embryonic stem cell complementation assay, it failed to produce any HAT-resistant clones, indicating an inability to rescue Brca2 loss-induced lethality. No further HDR or sensitivity assays were performed due to absence of viable clones. This supports a PS3 functional abnormal classification at a supporting strength.

summary: The c.7879A>T (p.Ile2627Phe) variant was identified by exact cDNA and protein match in Table 1. In a homology-directed repair assay using DR-GFP BRCA2-deficient V-C8 cells, the variant yielded an HDR score of 1.01 (upper 95% CI 1.18) compared to wild-type, indicating loss of function. The assay included immunoblot verification, replicate experiments, and known wild-type and pathogenic controls calibrated to yield an odds of pathogenicity >18.7. These well-validated functional data support application of PS3 strong evidence for pathogenicity.

summary: The variant N277K (p.Asn277Lys) was matched in the paper by the exact protein change. In mouse ES cell-based HAT assays, N277K fully rescued viability comparable to WT, and in drug sensitivity assays it exhibited resistance similar to WT across six DNA damaging agents. summary: The PTEN R14G variant was directly matched to the R14G substitution tested in Figure 5. In COS-7 cells, PTEN-GFP R14G accumulated abnormally in the nucleus (~90% nuclear) versus predominantly cytoplasmic WT. In yeast, R14G displayed markedly reduced PIP3-phosphatase activity (~15% cytoplasmic GFP-AKT1 vs ~80% for WT). These well-controlled assays demonstrate loss-of-function consistent with PTEN disease mechanism, supporting PS3_moderate evidence.

summary: The paper reports the FBN1 c.1708T>C (p.Cys570Arg, C570R) variant explicitly in exon 13. Quantitative pulse-chase assays in patient fibroblasts show ~50% protein synthesis and ~28% matrix deposition compared to WT, indicating an unstable, functionally abnormal protein. This supports a PS3_moderate level of functional evidence for pathogenicity.

summary: The DICER1 c.5425G>A (p.G1809R) variant was matched based on explicit labeling in Figure 1d and Figure 2b. In vitro pre-miRNA processing assays with immunopurified DICER1 G1809R showed loss of 5p miRNA cleavage and altered processing compared to wild type. These functional abnormalities indicate a damaging effect consistent with the disease mechanism. Accordingly, PS3 supporting evidence is assigned.

summary: The paper describes an exact protein-level match of DCLRE1C p.Asp136Asn (D136N, ARM18) in ARTEMIS. In vitro nuclease assays show that D136N abolishes endonucleolytic hairpin opening and overhang processing but retains normal exonuclease activity. In vivo V(D)J recombination assays demonstrate that D136N fails to rescue recombination in ARTEMIS-deficient fibroblasts. These functional defects support a PS3_moderate classification for D136N as damaging.

summary: The c.256_257del (frameshift K86VfsX33) variant in RAG1 is tested under the identical protein label in the paper. Flow cytometry–based GFP reporter assays and Western blotting demonstrate absent recombination activity and very low protein expression, and deep sequencing of Ighc rearrangements shows no detectable V(D)J recombination. These results support PS3_moderate for a deleterious effect consistent with loss of RAG1 function.

summary: The p.W453R variant in RAG2 is explicitly reported in this paper and matches the TARGET_VARIANT at the protein level. In an Abelson virus–transformed Rag2–/– pro-B cell recombination assay, W453R exhibited a marked decrease in DH–JH and Vκ–Jκ rearrangements compared to wild-type, and immunofluorescence showed partial cytoplasmic retention of the mutant protein. These results indicate a damaging effect on recombination activity and localization. Based on these functional abnormalities with WT comparators and basic controls, PS3_supporting evidence applies.

summary: The target variant c.829dup corresponds to the paper’s c.829insT (p.Y277fs) allele. In vitro V(D)J recombination assays show the p.Y227fs variant has zero activity and in combination with the E170G allele yields only 16.2% activity compared to wild-type. These results demonstrate loss-of-function, supporting PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The p.R229Q variant was matched by identical protein change and clear gene context. In a flow cytometry–based GFP reporter assay using Rag2−/− pro-B cells, R229Q exhibited severely reduced recombination activity (8.9% ±1.0% of WT) compared with wild-type RAG2 controls run in triplicate with negative controls. This functionally abnormal result supports a damaging effect on RAG2 activity. PS3_moderate evidence was assigned based on an established assay with appropriate controls.

summary: The R229Q mutation in RAG2 was directly modeled as a knockin in mice (Rag2R229Q/R229Q) and matched unambiguously by protein-level notation. Multiple in vivo functional assays demonstrate a severe block in V(D)J recombination, including arrest of thymocyte development at DN3, absence of B cell maturation, impaired T cell proliferation, hypogammaglobulinemia, reduced Aire expression, and decreased regulatory T cells. All assays use WT littermate comparators with significant differences. These results support a PS3 moderate classification for the pathogenic impact of RAG2 p.Arg229Gln.

summary: The variant c.241C>T (R81*) was matched exactly via HGVSc and protein labels in Tables 1 and 2. In a V(D)J recombination assay, R81* exhibited ~19% of WT GFP expression, and in a DNA repair assay showed ~16% of WT γH2AX dephosphorylation at 36h, both measured in Dclre1c−/− pro-B cells with WT and mock controls. These functionally abnormal results support a damaging loss-of-function effect consistent with the disease mechanism, qualifying for PS3_supporting evidence.

summary: The target p.L22P variant matches the ‘L22P’ site‐directed RPE65 mutant (Methods Table 2). In 293-F cells, RPE65/L22P showed markedly reduced isomerase activity (13.5% of wildtype, SD 1.6, n=6) and decreased protein expression (32.4% of wildtype, SD 7.64, n=4). These well‐controlled in vitro assays demonstrate functionally abnormal results relative to the wildtype comparator. Overall, this supports a PS3_moderate classification for p.L22P based on reduced enzymatic function and stability.

summary: The R515W variant is directly matched by protein notation p.R515W in the paper. Functional assays including immunoblot of expression, proteasome inhibition, misfolded aggregate formation, and retinoid isomerase activity demonstrate that R515W undergoes rapid proteasomal degradation, misfolding, and markedly reduced enzymatic function, with partial rescue at low temperature. This evidence supports applying PS3 at a moderate strength.

summary: The variant p.Ile130Thr was directly matched based on exact HGVSp and HGVSc notation in the Abstract and Table 1. Enzyme kinetic assays using purified GST-GK(p.Ile130Thr) showed significantly reduced Kcat, cooperativity and overall activity index relative to wild-type. These results support a damaging impact on glucokinase function consistent with MODY2. Overall, PS3 supportive evidence for pathogenicity is warranted.

summary: The authors performed an RT–PCR splicing assay on RNA from cells heterozygous for DICER1 c.5527+3A>G, showing a transcript lacking exon 25 compared to WT control and unaffected by NMD (Fig. 2b). This demonstrates that the variant disrupts the canonical splice donor site, leading to exon skipping and predicted protein truncation. Functional abnormality in RNA splicing supports a damaging effect. These results fulfill PS3 supporting evidence under ACMG/AMP guidelines for DICER1 c.5527+3A>G.

summary: The variant p.Gly331Ser (G331S) was directly matched in this paper. A RT-PCR splicing assay on patient blood RNA showed that the G331S mutation disrupts the final nucleotide of exon 7, causing exon 7 skipping compared to the WT full-length transcript. This abnormal splicing is consistent with a loss-of-function mechanism in HHT. Based on this functional abnormality with WT controls, a PS3_supporting level of evidence is assigned.

summary: The chrM_14512_CTA_C variant was strictly matched to the m.14512_14513del frameshift in MT-ND6. Histochemical and immunofluorescence analyses of patient muscle revealed ragged-red fibers and loss of NDUFB8, while BN-PAGE and SDS-PAGE immunoblots showed absence of fully assembled complex I and decreased complex I subunit levels. These well-controlled and replicated assays demonstrate a deleterious effect on complex I consistent with a truncating loss-of-function, supporting PS3_moderate.

summary: The RUNX1 p.K117* variant was directly matched by the same notation in Table 1 and Figures 2B/E with high confidence. In HeLa luciferase and Jurkat GFP reporter assays, p.K117* exhibited significantly reduced transcriptional activity compared with WT, indicating loss of function likely exacerbated by protein instability. These consistent functional abnormals support application of PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The variant p.F354S (c.1061T>C) in SLC26A4 is explicitly characterized in Table 1 and Figures 1a, 1b, and 2b, matching the TARGET_VARIANT with high confidence. Three functional assays (iodide influx, iodide efflux, and Cl-/OH- exchange) demonstrate that F354S activity is indistinguishable from wild-type pendrin. All assays included WT comparators, background and pathogenic controls, and technical replicates. These results provide moderate-strength BS3 evidence supporting a benign functional impact for this variant.

summary: The SCN2A p.A1773T (c.5317G>A) variant was matched based on exact protein and cDNA notation in the paper. Whole-cell patch clamp recordings in HEK293T cells showed significantly reduced current density, hyperpolarizing activation, depolarizing fast inactivation, and slower recovery versus WT, indicating a loss-of-function. Statistical significance was assessed by one-way ANOVA with Dunnett's test (n=12–15; p<0.05–0.01). These findings support a PS3_moderate level of functional evidence for pathogenicity.

summary: The variant c.2624T>C (p.Ile875Thr) was matched exactly by cDNA and protein notation. Electrophysiological recordings in tsA-201 cells expressing p.Ile875Thr channels showed a hyperpolarizing shift in activation (V₁/₂ –28.9 vs –15.9 mV, p<0.01) and a marked increase in persistent current (17.9 vs 2.6% INaP, p<0.001), indicating gain-of-function. Lacosamide selectively blocked 63.7% of the persistent current. These data support PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The VHL p.Leu188Val (L188V) variant is explicitly studied in this paper (labeled as VHLL188V) with high confidence. In COS-7 cells, co-expression of RSUME with VHLL188V stabilizes HIF-2α and increases HIF-driven luciferase activity relative to VHLL188V alone. In RCC 786-O clones, VHLL188V promotes elevated VEGF expression and conditioned-medium-driven endothelial tube formation and in vivo angiogenesis, all of which are reduced upon RSUME knockdown. These well-controlled assays demonstrate a loss-of-function effect consistent with aberrant HIF pathway activation, supporting a PS3 moderate classification.

summary: The variant p.L188V in VHL is a strict protein‐level match to the paper’s ‘L188V’ label. Co‐immunoprecipitation experiments in both Vhl-null mouse ES cells and human 786-0 RCC cells demonstrate that L188V pVHL binds Elongin C, Elongin B, CUL2 and ROC1 similarly to wild-type, indicating retained complex assembly. No direct HIF ubiquitylation or stability assays were performed for L188V in this study. These normal interaction results support BS3 at a supporting strength for p.L188V.

summary: The p.Leu188Val (L188V) variant was directly matched to pVHLL188V in the paper via consistent protein nomenclature. Multiple assays demonstrate that L188V destabilizes the VCB complex, causing temperature-sensitive assembly defects, increased aggregation and proteolytic susceptibility, and loss of native fold by NMR, as well as impaired CBCVHL assembly and HIF-1α down-regulation in cells. These functional defects are supported by robust WT and negative controls across biochemical and cellular systems. On balance, the evidence meets PS3 with moderate strength for a damaging effect on VHL function.

summary: The variant VHL c.562C>G (p.L188V) is an exact cDNA and protein match in the paper. Functional assays using primary erythroid progenitors from a heterozygous carrier showed no hypersensitivity to EPO (functionally normal), and HIF1A binding and ubiquitination assays in 786-0 cells revealed normal activity. However, cycloheximide chase assays demonstrated a marked decrease in mutant protein stability. Given these conflicting results, the functional evidence for p.L188V is classified as not_clear for PS3/BS3.

summary: The VHL p.Phe91Leu (F91L) variant was directly tested in biotinylated HIFα peptide pull-down assays using IVTT-expressed HA-VHL(F91L). The assay demonstrated abolished binding to both hydroxylated HIF1α and HIF2α peptides relative to WT. This loss-of-binding supports a damaging effect on VHL’s regulation of HIFα. Based on the presence of a WT comparator and established assay, PS3 supporting evidence is assigned.

summary: The variant V30I was matched by exact protein notation in Figure 2 of the paper. In HEK293T cells, V30I shows reduced SCSR and STR secretion (~25% of WT), decreased intracellular expression, and a 2.2-fold increased relative g-carboxylation efficiency. These functional abnormalities, with appropriate WT controls and replicates, support a deleterious effect. PS3_supporting evidence is assigned based on these cell-based assays.

summary: The m.8340G>A variant was matched exactly via its genomic coordinate. In patient muscle, COX histochemistry, sequential COX–SDH staining, OXPHOS immunofluorescence, and single-fibre PCR segregation demonstrate a mosaic respiratory chain defect and significantly increased heteroplasmy in COX-deficient fibers, confirming pathogenicity. These functional data support a PS3 designation at moderate strength.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT chrM_5610_G_A matches the m.5610G>A variant in the mt-tRNAAla gene by exact genomic coordinate. Single-fibre segregation studies demonstrate significantly higher mutation loads in COX-deficient fibres (98.0% vs 78.9%, P=0.0002), high-resolution northern blot shows dramatically decreased mt-tRNAAla steady-state levels, and spectrophotometric assays reveal decreased complexes I and IV activities with compensatory citrate synthase increase. These consistent functional deficits support a damaging effect on mitochondrial function. PS3_moderate is assigned, given the well-established assays with statistical and control validation.

summary: The variant Y1146C (c.3437A>G) was directly studied and matched by cDNA and protein notation. Multiple in vitro assays including ELISA-based secretion/retention, multimer analysis, immunofluorescence of WPB formation, and FVIII binding demonstrated significant functional defects relative to WT. These results support a damaging loss-of-function effect consistent with VWD pathogenesis. PS3 evidence is applied at moderate strength.

summary: The paper strictly matches the TARGET_VARIANT m.14597A>G (p.Ile26Thr) in MT-ND6 via genomic coordinate and protein notation. Transmitochondrial cybrid lines with this variant showed severely reduced complex I activity (~10% of control), impaired growth in galactose medium (~70–80% of control), decreased ATP production (~50% of control), and reduced oxygen consumption rate (~70% of control), consistent with a mitochondrial complex I defect. The overall functional evidence meets PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The study engineers the p.V1316M substitution (V1316M, CTG->ATG) in murine Vwf, matching the human VWF p.V1316M variant. Functional characterization in plasma, washed platelets, whole blood perfusion, in vivo thrombosis and bleeding, VWF-string formation, and inflammation models shows consistently abnormal results compared to WT controls. These assays demonstrate loss of high molecular weight multimers, impaired platelet function, severe hemostatic defects, and altered VWF-string behavior, supporting a damaging effect. This evidence fulfills PS3 at a moderate level.

summary: The paper directly studies p.Arg1597Trp (R1597W) in VWF by expressing full-length VWF in HEK293 cells and demonstrating enhanced ADAMTS13 proteolysis. Purified VWF A2 FRET constructs with R1597W show reduced folding stability (Kurea 1.22 vs 2.16 M for WT) and accelerated cleavage kinetics (t1/2 16.9 min vs no WT cleavage). These consistent in vitro functional abnormalities support a PS3_supporting classification for this pathogenic variant.

summary: The variant p.R1597W (R1597W) in VWF was clearly matched by protein-level notation in the paper. In vitro ADAMTS13 digestion showed enhanced cleavage (EC50 0.109 vs 0.341 U/ml), and in vivo mouse models demonstrated decreased multimer size, accelerated clearance (shorter half-life and increased VWFpp/VWF:Ag ratio), reduced VWF antigen levels, and impaired thrombosis. Western blot and thrombosis assays further confirmed increased proteolysis and reduced occlusive clot formation. These consistent functional abnormalities support a PS3 moderate-level classification for a damaging effect consistent with type 2A VWD.

summary: The variant p.Arg1399His (R1399H, rs1800382) was identified in the paper as R1399H in the VWF A1 domain (strict protein and rsID match). Patient plasma from heterozygous carriers showed reduced VWF:CB/VWF:Ag ratios with type VI collagen. Recombinant homozygous 1399H VWF expressed in HEK293T cells exhibited near-complete loss of type VI collagen binding (≈5% of WT, p<0.001). Together, these results demonstrate a damaging functional effect on type VI collagen binding, supporting a PS3 criterion at moderate strength.

summary: The V1314D variant (p.Val1314Asp) in VWF was directly matched to the paper’s V1314D label in the A1A2A3 constructs. Limited trypsinolysis (Fig 4B) and HXMS (Fig 7A,C) in recombinant A1A2A3 show increased proteolysis rates (7.4-fold) and enhanced deuterium exchange in α2 and allosteric regions, indicating local unfolding. In a shear flow platelet adhesion assay (Fig 7B), V1314D causes irreversible, high-affinity platelet binding. Together these assays demonstrate functionally abnormal gain-of-function consistent with misfolding, supporting a PS3 moderate evidence classification.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT c.686A>G (p.Asp229Gly) was matched directly in the paper by exact protein and cDNA nomenclature. Functional studies in E. coli showed severely impaired oligomerization (4.1% ± 3.7% tetramers vs 58.7% ± 15.2% WT) and null residual enzymatic activity (0% ± 0%), while HepG2 cell expression demonstrated markedly reduced PAH protein levels with partial rescue by BH4 precursor. These results are consistent with a damaging loss-of-function effect, supporting PS3_moderate.

summary: The LDLR variant p.D482H was directly matched in the paper and shown to be retained in the ER by immunofluorescence, to lack mature glycosylation, and to be misfolded as indicated by loss of C7 antibody binding and Endo H sensitivity. D482H expression induced ER stress (XBP-1 splicing), displayed enhanced binding to ER chaperones and ERAD factors, and was stabilized by proteasome inhibition, consistent with accelerated ERAD. These results support aberrant functional impact of p.D482H, satisfying PS3 with moderate strength.

summary: The paper reports the Ser580Phe (p.Ser580Phe) variant in LDLR, matching the target variant by exact protein notation. Functional DiI-LDL uptake assays in primary monocytes and lymphocytes from patient PBMCs showed >45% reductions in LDL uptake and organelle counts compared to pooled healthy controls (p<0.001). These results demonstrate a loss-of-function effect, supporting PS3 at a supporting level.

summary: The paper describes the de novo heterozygous MRAS variant p.Gly23Val (c.68G>T) matching the TARGET_VARIANT exactly in both cDNA and protein notation. Functional assays in HEK293T/17 and MEF cells demonstrated 4–40-fold increased GTP loading, enhanced ERK phosphorylation, and elevated SRE-driven transcription relative to WT-MRAS, consistent with a gain-of-function effect. These findings provide PS3_moderate evidence supporting pathogenicity for the variant.

summary: The variant p.R369W was directly evaluated in muscle cells via overexpression. In de novo actin polymerization assays, R369W-transfected myoblasts showed a significant reduction in new actin filament formation compared to WT. In TIRF-based GLUT4 trafficking assays, R369W markedly impaired stimulus-dependent insertion of endogenous GLUT4 into the plasma membrane. These consistent functionally abnormal results support a PS3 classification at moderate strength due to clear controls, replication, and statistical validation.

summary: The DNM2 p.Ala618Thr (A618T) variant, confirmed by direct protein-level match, binds PtdIns(4,5)P2 with wild-type affinity. However, it exhibits a ~1.7-fold increase in basal GTPase activity and ~2-fold higher lipid-stimulated GTP hydrolysis rates compared with wild type in multiple in vitro assays. These results demonstrate a functionally abnormal gain-of-function effect consistent with the known disease mechanism of centronuclear myopathy, supporting a PS3_moderate classification.

overall_evidence.basis: Assembly-dependent GTPase activation and oligomerization are hyperactive relative to WT, consistent with gain-of-function disease mechanism; PIP2 binding and phosphorylation are unchanged with high variant match confidence

summary: The target p.Ala618Thr (A618T) variant was exactly matched to DNM2A618T in the paper. In vitro assays show A618T causes enhanced polymer stability and GTPase activation, and cellular analyses reveal higher-order oligomer formation and slower diffusion, while PIP2 binding and tyrosine phosphorylation remain normal. These consistent gain-of-function findings support application of PS3 at a moderate strength for this variant.

summary: The variant p.Arg465Trp (R465W) was matched in the paper by its exact protein notation and examined in Figure 3. Turbidity assays (Fig. 3B) show R465W polymers are resistant to GTP-induced disassembly, and GTPase assays (Fig. 3D) demonstrate increased activity at low protein concentrations. These in vitro biochemical findings indicate a functionally abnormal effect consistent with a pathogenic mechanism, supporting a PS3 supporting classification.

summary: The MTM1 p.Pro205Leu (P205L) variant was matched directly based on identical protein nomenclature in Fig. 3. In vitro phosphatase assays using recombinant protein showed that P205L has virtually no activity toward both pNPP and the physiologic substrate PI(3)P compared with wild-type. These experiments demonstrate a clear loss-of-function effect. Overall, this supports applying PS3_supporting for this variant.

summary: The paper reports murine Mtm1 c.205C>T (p.R69C) matching human MTM1 p.R69C. RT–PCR in mouse tissues and minigene assays show predominant exon 4 skipping producing out-of-frame transcripts, and splicing is likewise altered in patient muscle. A lipid ELISA reveals elevated PI3P in Mtm1 p.R69C muscle versus wild-type. These functionally abnormal results support a damaging effect (PS3_moderate).

summary: The c.19097G>T (p.Ser6366Ile) NEB variant is directly modelled as the NebS6366I allele in mice (matched by cDNA and protein). NebS6366I homozygous mice display normal nebulin expression but have reduced in vivo and ex vivo muscle force, nemaline rod bodies in EDL, and altered thin filament length. These well-controlled functional assays support PS3_moderate evidence that p.Ser6366Ile is deleterious.

summary: The paper matched the TARGET_VARIANT p.M90V (RIT1 p.M90V) directly in multiple experiments. In HEK293T cells, p.M90V exhibited increased binding to the PAK1 CRIB domain and enhanced co-immunoprecipitation with PAK1, CDC42, and RAC1, with some increases reaching statistical significance. In COS7 cells, expression of p.M90V led to loss of actin stress fibers, and in HEK293T cells it enhanced migration in a transwell assay. These data support PS3 at a supporting level.

summary: We matched the target variant p.N583S to the deep mutational scanning dataset via explicit protein-level matching. In the massively parallel 6-TG selection assay in HAP1 MSH2 knockout cells, p.N583S exhibited a negative LoF score, indicating functional neutrality relative to wild-type. The assay included wild-type and pathogenic controls, replicate selections, and FDR estimation. We assign BS3 moderate evidence for the neutrality of p.N583S.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT (NRAS c.173C>T, p.Thr58Ile) is strictly matched in the paper by exact cDNA and protein notation. In HEK293T cells, the Thr58Ile variant shows increased GTP-bound active form and elevated ERK and AKT phosphorylation compared to WT, with appropriate WT and positive controls. These functional data support a gain-of-function mechanism consistent with pathogenic RASopathy variants. PS3 evidence is met with moderate strength.

summary: The variant p.Q1489K was exactly matched as 'Q1489K' in SCN1A. In tsA201 cells, Q1489K exhibits normal peak current and activation but shows abnormal gating with slower recovery from fast inactivation, increased persistent current, accelerated entry into slow inactivation with altered recovery, and marked use-dependent loss of availability compared to WT. These functional abnormalities, observed in well-controlled electrophysiology experiments, support a pathogenic effect (PS3_moderate).

summary: The paper explicitly studies the familial hemiplegic migraine mutation Q1489K (cloned as Q1478K) in SCN1A and matches the target variant with high confidence. In tsA-201 cells, whole-cell and use-dependent recordings reveal reduced peak current, depolarizing shifts in inactivation, increased persistent current, and altered fast and slow inactivation kinetics. In rat neurons, macropatch and current-clamp assays demonstrate reduced peak INa, shifted inactivation, increased early firing currents, and enhanced initial action potential frequency that is self-limited during prolonged depolarization. These well-controlled functional assays support a PS3 moderate level of evidence for a functionally abnormal effect of Q1489K.

summary: The paper describes a 6-bp deletion in exon 28 of VWF, deleting D1529V1530 (DD1529V1530), which matches the TARGET_VARIANT c.4586_4591del. In HEK293 cells, the mutant exhibits increased intracellular retention and markedly reduced secretion and HMW multimer formation by ELISA and multimer analysis, and colocalizes with ER marker by immunofluorescence. These consistent functional defects support a PS3 level of evidence at moderate strength for a damaging effect.

The authors performed α-iduronidase activity assays in HAP1 IDUA-KO cells expressing p.Glu182Lys and quantified enzyme activity via 4-MUI substrate normalized to WT-1B3 and protein abundance, finding near-zero specific activity (0.001–0.03% of WT). summary: The paper characterizes the VWF A1 domain variant S1285F (p.Ser1285Phe) in biophysical and functional assays. summary: The LDLR p.His583Tyr variant matched exactly the paper's protein label. Functional assays in T-Rex CHO cells demonstrated abnormal ER retention by live imaging, reduced surface localization (40±3% of WT) and LDL internalization (52±12% of WT) by flow cytometry, and induction of ER stress chaperones Hsp90b1 and Hspa5 (~2.3–2.6-fold). These consistent findings support PS3 at moderate strength for a deleterious effect on LDLR function.

summary: The IDUA p.Pro533Arg variant was matched directly to the Pro533Arg mutation studied in the paper. Enzyme kinetics assays revealed a ~2-fold reduction in Vmax with unchanged Km, and thermal stability assays showed reduced residual activity after heat treatment compared to wild-type. Both assays demonstrate a functionally abnormal effect relative to wild-type IDUA. These results support a PS3 (functional evidence of pathogenicity) at a supporting strength for the p.Pro533Arg variant.

summary: The SGCA p.Arg77Cys (R77C) variant was directly tested via transient expression in 4-HEK cells. Western blot and densitometry revealed ~40% expression vs WT, with increased ubiquitination upon proteasome inhibition. Biotinylation and immunofluorescence showed failure to reach the cell surface, while confocal microscopy demonstrated intracellular aggregation. Co-immunoprecipitation indicated a lack of stable complex formation with other sarcoglycans. These consistent functional abnormalities support PS3_moderate.

summary: The paper reports the GUCY2D variant S248W (p.Ser248Trp) matching the TARGET_VARIANT by exact protein notation. In vivo electroretinography and guanylyl cyclase activity assays in GCdKO mouse retinas expressing AAV-delivered S248W GUCY2D showed absent scotopic and minimal photopic responses and undetectable RetGC1 activity compared to robust wild-type controls. In vitro RD3 inhibition assays demonstrated that the S248W variant retains normal RD3 sensitivity, but immunoblot and immunofluorescence revealed markedly reduced protein expression and mislocalization in photoreceptors. Collectively, these results support PS3_moderate evidence that S248W impairs GUCY2D function via deficient expression/processing.

summary: The variant p.P575L was matched to the paper's 'P575L' experiments with medium confidence based on an exact protein notation match in GUCY2D, with cellular localization and basal activity similar to WT. However, GCAP-mediated Ca2+-sensitive activation showed a two-fold shift to lower IC50 values, indicating dysregulated Ca2+ sensitivity. Apparent GCAP affinities (EC50) remained similar to WT. These data support PS3_moderate evidence for a damaging functional effect due to abnormal Ca2+-regulated activation.

notes: Exact HGVSc notation c.182A>G used for overexpression in functional assay

experiments.assay: In vivo thrombocyte rescue assay measuring cd41:eGFP+ thrombocytes
experiments.variant_material: Injected human GP9 c.182A>G (hsGP9182A>G) mRNA
experiments.readout: Number of cd41:eGFP^high thrombocytes in the caudal hematopoietic tissue at 4 dpf
experiments.normal_comparator: gp9SMU15 mutants injected with human GP9 wild-type mRNA and WT sibling embryos

result.effect_size_and_stats: gp9SMU15+hsGP9182A>G: ~21±2 cells vs gp9SMU15+hsGP9WT: ~34±2 cells (n≈10; p<0.0001 for WT rescue; non-significant vs gp9SMU15 control)

experiments.controls_and_validation: Positive control: hsGP9WT mRNA injection rescues thrombocytopenia; negative control: gp9SMU15 uninjected; n≥10; Student t-test
experiments.authors_conclusion: The GP9 c.182A>G mutation is loss-of-function and fails to rescue thrombocytopoiesis

overall_evidence.validation_basis: Rescue assay with WT and variant controls, n≥10, statistical significance, clear phenotype reversal only with WT mRNA
overall_evidence.basis: Human GP9 c.182A>G fails to rescue thrombocytopenia in zebrafish gp9SMU15 model (abnormal function vs WT comparator), consistent with loss-of-function disease mechanism

summary: The GP9 c.182A>G (p.N61S, rs5030764) variant matches exactly the cDNA notation used in the paper. In an in vivo zebrafish rescue assay, injection of human GP9 c.182A>G mRNA into gp9-deficient larvae failed to restore cd41:eGFP^high thrombocyte counts in the caudal hematopoietic tissue, unlike wild-type GP9 mRNA. This demonstrates a functionally abnormal, loss-of-function effect consistent with the disease mechanism in BSS, supporting PS3 at moderate strength.

overall_evidence.validation_basis: well-established assays with clear WT comparators and multiple replication
overall_evidence.basis: Multiple independent functional assays in cybrid cells and in vitro demonstrate that m.4295A>G causes abnormal tRNAIle modification, processing, structure, aminoacylation, downstream mitochondrial translation and bioenergetics consistent with disease mechanism

summary: The m.4295A>G mitochondrial tRNAIle mutation was matched by exact genomic coordinate and HGVS notation in the paper. Functional experiments in cybrid cells and in vitro show that the mutation introduces an m1G37 modification, reduces 5′ end processing and aminoacylation, destabilizes tRNAIle, and leads to decreased tRNA steady‐state levels. Downstream assays demonstrate impaired mitochondrial translation, OXPHOS complex assembly and activity, reduced respiration, Δψm and ATP production, and increased ROS and autophagy. Together, these well‐controlled assays support a PS3_moderate classification for this pathogenic variant.

summary: The variant c.1088C>A (p.Thr363Asn) was explicitly matched by cDNA and protein notation in Table 1 and Figure 3B. High-throughput microscopy in CHO-ldlA7 cells using transient transfection and WT comparator showed 90–95% LDLR expression and 95–98% LDL uptake of WT levels, indicating functionally normal behavior. The assay included known benign and pathogenic controls with clear replication and thresholds. Based on these results, the variant shows normal function and meets BS3 moderate criteria.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT c.1316G>A (p.G439D) is strictly matched in Table 1 of the paper as part of genotype 24 (compound heterozygous A304T/G439D). In patient fibroblasts, FAO flux and VLCAD enzyme activity assays demonstrated markedly reduced function at baseline and only partial increases after bezafibrate treatment, with levels remaining below wild-type controls. These results support a PS3_supporting classification for this variant’s functional impact, noting uncertainty due to the compound heterozygous background.

overall_evidence.basis: Multiple orthogonal assays show reduced steady-state levels and stability of mt-tRNAVal C25U relative to WT, consistent with a damaging effect on tRNA stability, with clear comparators and minimal variant matching uncertainty

summary: The mitochondrial 1624C>T (mt-tRNAVal C25U) variant was matched with high confidence by exact genomic coordinate and nomenclature. High-resolution northern blots in patient tissues and myoblasts demonstrated markedly reduced mt-tRNAVal levels (<1% in muscle, ~9–11% in cells) and ethidium bromide chase assays showed shortened tRNA half-life (~50–65% of WT). Rescue experiments with translation inhibitors and inducible VARS2L overexpression partially restored mt-tRNAVal levels. These data support a damaging effect on tRNA stability consistent with PS3 at a moderate strength level.

summary: The p.G275S variant (c.823G>A, rs62642057) in RPGR was directly matched in the paper as G275S. In RPE1 cells, GFP-tagged RPGR1−19 G275S failed to localize to primary cilia, and in HEK293T cells co-immunoprecipitation assays showed markedly reduced interaction of G275S in RPGR1−19, RPGRORF15, and shared constructs with endogenous PDE6D, INPP5E, and RPGRIP1L. These consistent abnormal functional results support PS3 evidence at moderate strength for a damaging effect.

In mouse embryonic stem cells, p.K2657T displays function scores in DMSO, cisplatin, and olaparib conditions consistent with wild-type. summary: The variant BRCA1 c.5152+6T>C (rs80358074) was matched by exact cDNA and rsID in Table 4 and Figure 2 of the paper. RT-PCR and Sanger sequencing on patient lymphocyte-derived cDNA revealed exon 18 skipping and an in-frame 26 amino acid deletion in the BRCT domain. This abnormal splicing, observed against a wild-type control, supports a damaging effect. Based on this functional evidence, PS3_supporting is applied, although further studies are recommended to confirm pathogenicity.

summary: The variant p.K125E in PTEN is directly matched by the paper’s PTENK125E label (protein-level match, medium confidence). Multiple functional assays in MCF-7 and HEK293 systems demonstrate that PTENK125E loses lipid phosphatase activity (unchanged P-AKT and cyclin D1), fails to stabilize nuclear p53 or support p53 transcriptional activity, and leads to increased oxidative stress and DNA double-strand breaks, with stable protein levels comparable to wild-type. These results indicate a damaging effect consistent with the disease mechanism, supporting PS3 at a moderate strength.

summary: PTEN p.K125E (K125E) is directly assayed in this paper (matched at protein level with medium confidence). Cycloheximide chase and MG-132 experiments show K125E protein stability and proteasomal degradation are normal. Proteasome activity assays in whole cells and subcellular fractions likewise show no proteasome hyperactivity. However, P-AKT suppression assays demonstrate impaired lipid phosphatase activity relative to WT, consistent with a damaging loss-of-function effect. These data support PS3 at the supporting level for p.K125E.

summary: The paper directly tests the p.C330Y (C330Y-substituted Rpe65) variant in 293T-LC cell isomerase assays. Cells expressing C330Y produced no 11cROL from atROL, whereas WT Rpe65 produced ~9 pmol per dish. Proper expression of the mutant was confirmed by immunoblot. summary: The variant p.Gly189Arg (G189R) in the KCNQ1 C-loop was an exact protein match to one of the mutants tested. In HEK293T cells co-expressing WT and G189R subunits, basal IKs current was significantly reduced and PKA-mediated forskolin activation was abolished compared to WT. These well-controlled patch clamp experiments support a loss-of-function effect consistent with type-1 long QT syndrome. This functional evidence fulfills PS3 at a moderate strength.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT p.Ala300Thr (A300T) is explicitly tested in this study (Figure 3). Automated patch clamp in CHO-K1 cells demonstrates A300T has ~350% of WT current density at +60 mV and a +25 mV shift in activation V½. Experiments included WT and non-transfected controls with HMR1556 subtraction and were benchmarked against manual patch clamp. These consistent gain-of-function findings support PS3_moderate for A300T.

summary: We matched the TARGET_VARIANT p.G589D to the "G589D" variant studied in the paper. Functional assays in CHO and adult rat cardiomyocytes demonstrate that G589D homotetrameric channels produce no IKs, heterotetrameric channels recover only ~30% of WT current, and quantum-dot labeling shows significantly reduced surface expression. These consistent loss-of-function findings support applying PS3 at moderate strength for this variant.

summary: The KCNQ1 variant L273V was identified by direct protein notation matching. In Xenopus oocytes, homomeric L273V channels showed increased currents, but in the physiologically relevant heterozygous condition with KCNE1 the variant exhibited a marked IKs loss-of-function with reduced peak currents and a depolarizing V1/2 shift. These robust, statistically significant findings support a damaging effect (PS3_moderate).

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT p.S529V is explicitly studied in HEK293T cells (Table 1). S529V exhibits only 9% of wild-type GAA activity in enzymatic assays, which modestly increases to 12% after bortezomib treatment (1.3-fold, p<0.05). The significant baseline reduction in activity relative to WT supports a loss-of-function effect. No additional assays for this variant are reported. PS3 supporting is applied based on reduced enzymatic activity with appropriate controls.

summary: The p.T60I (Thr60Ile) variant was directly tested and matched by exact protein notation in the paper. Yeast two-hybrid assays show abolished GK–GKRP interaction, in vitro enzyme kinetics reveal dramatically reduced catalytic efficiency, GKRP inhibition assays demonstrate insensitivity to inhibition, and cell-based imaging shows loss of GK nuclear localization. These well-validated, independent functional studies support PS3_moderate evidence for a damaging effect consistent with a loss-of-function mechanism.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT c.-40+1G>A was directly matched to the paper’s described splice donor site mutation. Human cell RT-PCR revealed aberrant splicing using an alternative donor site. In mouse ES cells, c.-40+1G>A led to significantly reduced BRCA2 transcript levels, severely impaired viability rescue and hypersensitivity to DNA-damaging agents compared to WT. These consistent loss-of-function results support PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The GAA c.1880C>T (p.Ser627Phe) variant was identified in patient-derived iPSCMyoD clones (Pom1a/b) by cDNA sequencing. Lysosomal GAA activity assays in undifferentiated Pom1 clones demonstrated markedly reduced enzyme activity (~20 vs 100 nmol/mg/hr in WT; p<0.001). Differentiated Pom1 myocytes exhibited increased lysosomal glycogen accumulation after glucose deprivation (~100 vs 20 µg/mg protein; p<0.001). These functional assays support a damaging effect consistent with GAA loss-of-function, fulfilling PS3 at moderate strength.

summary: The paper reports p.Met121Arg (c.362T>G) with exact cDNA and protein notation (high confidence match). In HEK293 cells, Western blot and ELISA show markedly reduced secretion and elevated intracellular AT, while RT-qPCR and activity assays indicate normal mRNA and catalytic function; PNGase digestion confirms normal glycosylation. These results demonstrate a secretion defect consistent with antithrombin loss-of-function, supporting a PS3_moderate classification.

summary: The RS1 c.421C>T (p.Arg141Cys, R141C) substitution was exactly introduced in a knock-in mouse model and matched unambiguously to the TARGET_VARIANT. Extensive functional characterization shows abnormal RS1 localization, markedly reduced RS1 protein levels, severe retinal schisis, negative ERG waveforms with greater b-wave reduction, abnormal cone ERG responses, retinal cell neurite sprouting, gliosis, and impaired retinal ganglion cell signaling. These well-controlled, statistically significant results constitute PS3 evidence at a moderate strength for a damaging effect of R141C.

Two immunoblot assays in COS-7 cells demonstrate complete loss of mature RS1 secretion and proteasomal degradation of unprocessed precursor for p.Leu13Pro, relative to WT and positive controls. These results support a functionally abnormal null-protein phenotype, satisfying PS3 (supporting).

summary: The paper directly tests the AIPL1 p.L17P variant (c.50T>C) and shows impaired co-chaperone binding to HSP90 in both Y2H and quantitative ELISA assays. In cells, p.L17P fails to recruit PDE6a from the ER to the cytosol and does not enhance cGMP hydrolysis by the PDE6 holoenzyme. These consistent loss-of-function results support PS3 moderate evidence for pathogenicity.

summary: The AIPL1 p.Cys89Arg (C89R) variant was matched by exact protein change in the paper. In HEK293T cells, C89R failed to chaperone PDE6C, showing background cGMP hydrolysis compared to robust activity with WT AIPL1 (Fig. 5B,C). In COS7 cells, C89R formed nuclear/perinuclear inclusion bodies, indicating misfolding (Fig. 6B). These results provide PS3 (moderate) evidence for a deleterious effect of C89R.

summary: The paper explicitly reports p.S310Y (S310Y) as one of the analyzed variants. Size-exclusion chromatography showed that S310Y formed only high-molecular-weight aggregates with no detectable tetramers (100% aggregates vs 0% in WT). This indicates a severe folding defect and loss of normal oligomerization. These results support PS3_supporting evidence for a damaging effect consistent with PAH deficiency.

summary: The mitochondrial tRNAThr variant m.15915 G>A (G30A) was matched by exact genomic coordinate. Functional assays showed G30A markedly reduces aminoacylation efficiency (14% of WT), impairs total and post-transfer editing (43% of WT; slight deacylation decrease), and decreases t6A37 modification (41% of WT). Binding assays demonstrated weakened hmThrRS–tRNA affinity and altered Qri7–tRNA interaction. These results support PS3_moderate for a damaging effect of G30A.

summary: The paper tests cTnI R193H, a rodent analog of human TNNI3 R192H, matched heuristically by the identical Arg>His substitution and disease context. In intact adult rat myocytes expressing the mutant, sarcomere relaxation is markedly slowed and Ca2+ transient decay is prolonged relative to WT, and resting sarcomere length is shortened independent of diastolic Ca2+. These results demonstrate a functionally abnormal phenotype consistent with gain-of-function disease mechanism. Overall, PS3 moderate evidence is satisfied for the variant based on established assays with clear WT comparators and robust replication.

summary: The human TNNI3 p.R192H variant is studied as the R192H mutant (cTnI193His) transgene in mouse TnI, confirmed by clear mention of R192H and cTnI193His in the Abstract. Doppler echocardiography in these mice shows impaired relaxation with reversed E/A and E′/A′ ratios, prolonged IVRT and DT. Ex vivo working heart studies reveal decreased stroke volume, reduced ±dP/dt and prolonged relaxation times, and in vivo dobutamine stress fails to increase cardiac output. These consistent functionally abnormal findings across multiple assays support a PS3 moderate classification for this variant.

summary: The TNNI3 p.Arg192His (R192H) variant corresponds directly to the TnI R192H label used throughout the paper. In isolated troponin complexes, R192H shows no change in Ca2+ sensitivity or dissociation rate relative to WT. In thin filament reconstitutions, R192H significantly sensitizes Ca2+ binding (Kd 1.59 µM vs 4.5 µM WT), slows Ca2+ dissociation (koff 72 vs 109 s⁻¹), and increases Ca2+ association rate (kon 48 vs 9 ×10⁶ M⁻¹ s⁻¹). These functionally abnormal results with appropriate WT controls support a PS3_supporting classification.

summary: The paper evaluates the mouse R193H troponin I mutation (corresponding to human p.R192H) using actomyosin ATPase assays. R193H exhibits increased ATPase activity relative to wild-type in both Ca²⁺ and EGTA conditions, while maximal activation by NEM-S1 is normal, indicating stabilization of the active thin filament state. These functional abnormalities support a PS3 (supporting) classification, though the variant match is heuristic to the mouse residue numbering.

summary: The paper studies a cTnI R193H transgenic mouse model, explicitly linked to the human R192H variant. Biochemical assays show increased myofilament Ca2+ sensitivity and delayed Ca2+ transients relative to WT, indicating abnormal function. Rescue experiments with cTnI-ND and EGCg normalize Ca2+ sensitivity and diastolic function in vivo. These findings support PS3 at moderate strength for p.Arg192His.

summary: The paper describes the ACTC E99K (p.Glu101Lys) mutation, matched by protein labeling and numbering context. Multiple functional assays, including in vitro motility and skinned papillary muscle, show that E99K actin increases Ca2+ sensitivity and reduces sliding speed, and uncouples the normal troponin I phosphorylation effect. These results provide PS3 functional evidence at moderate strength for a damaging effect consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

overall_evidence.basis: Multiple ex vivo and in vitro assays consistently show E143K myosin hypercontractility, increased binding affinity, ATPase activity, impaired relaxation kinetics, increased fiber stiffness and altered sarcomere structure, supporting a damaging functional effect consistent with disease mechanism

summary: The MYL3 p.Glu143Lys (E143K) variant was directly matched via identical protein notation throughout the paper. Functional characterization of E143K myosin in transgenic mouse fibers and purified protein assays revealed increased active tension, Ca2+ sensitivity, myofiber stiffness, actin-binding affinity, ATPase activity, slowed acto-myosin dissociation, and altered step dynamics, along with reduced RLC phosphorylation. These consistent abnormal results establish pathogenic functional evidence (PS3) at a moderate strength level.

summary: The TARGET_VARIANT p.E143K in MYL3 is a direct match by protein notation in the paper. Functional assays demonstrate abnormal biochemical and biophysical properties: increased actin-activated ATPase Vmax, shortened intermediate step-size in single-molecule stepping, and reduced power output under load, although unloaded motility velocity is preserved. These well-controlled and statistically significant results support a PS3 moderate-level classification for the variant.

summary: The paper clearly characterizes the TNNT2 c.851+1G>A (Int15G→A) splice donor site mutation. In quail myotubes, the truncated TnT incorporates into sarcomeres (79% normal structure, 21% with collapse) but causes a severe reduction in calcium-activated force (0.30 vs 1.32 kg/cm2 in WT) and complete loss of force in disrupted fibers. Co-expression with wild-type yields force outputs ranging from 10–100% of control. These robust functional assays support PS3_moderate evidence for a damaging effect.

experiments.controls_and_validation: n=6 control hearts, n=5 Tg hearts; multiple workloads; statistical significance by unpaired Student’s t test

overall_evidence.basis: The transgene modeling c.851+1G>A shows abnormal sarcomeric incorporation and impaired cardiac function consistent with a damaging effect

summary: The paper explicitly models the splice-site donor mutation c.851+1G>A in TNNT2 by expressing a truncated cTnT transgene. Fractionation assays show the truncated protein has reduced incorporation into myofibrils, and isolated perfused heart experiments demonstrate significantly impaired relaxation and contraction compared to wild type. These well-controlled functional studies support PS3 moderate evidence for a damaging effect of the splice-site variant.

summary: p.R653C (p.Arg653Cys) was strictly matched by protein-level notation. In HEK293T-derived, immunoaffinity-purified ABCA4 assays, p.R653C exhibited WT-like basal ATPase but no significant ATPase activation by N-Ret-PE and was deficient in substrate binding compared to WT. These functional deficits support a PS3 supporting classification.
